game-hours: 389.0
review: PIU PIU PIU
game-hours: 646.1
review: This makes me spend to much money.
game-hours: 671.2
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive doesn't need any introduction. Counter-Strike is one of the most popular franchises on PC. Global Offensive brought a new look to it, literally. Graphics were tweaked to "battle" against the other modernized FPS games who were already on the market or coming near to release. The classic and old maps from the previous Counter-Strikes' are polished to match the game quality and are actually still enjoyable. You still have the feeling you are playing Counter-Strike, even if the characters voices were completely changed. In the terms of gameplay, nothing much has changed, besides the HUD/UI. Global Offensive, like the previous ones, is a competitive tactical shooter. The new incendiary grenade on this game gives it a nice touch, but it can lead you to a terrible loss of frame-rate if you have a weak computer. (as well as smokes and flashbangs sometimes) What we can really call "new", is the ability to find official matches to play on the official CS:GO servers. The matchmaking system brings a new life to the game when it comes to play with friends, or just make your way to the top rankings by winning official ranked matches. CS:GO allows you to make a specific lobby for any mode and map you wish to play and, the best part, WITH friends! In every previous CS games, I sometimes had the feeling that I would have to be very lucky to find, not only, a server that I was exactly looking for, and with slots enough to play with my friends (in the same team). The CS:GO matchmaking eliminates this hassle and makes everything faster and easier. I still dislike not being able to tell the game how many players you are looking for. (for example: 2vs2, 3vs3, 4vs4, and so on) You can still join player created dedicted servers just like you did in the previous Counter-Strikes', so don't worry. :) The ability to watch other players matches (friends or not) with a 30 second delay was a nice play by the developers. You can now safely play a match without worrying about spectators helping someone on the opposite side team. And above all it allows you to watch some popular clans and pro players battle each other, which is always enjoyable to watch. (like tournaments happening in that moment) Which then leads to one of the biggest problems on every multiplayer game: cheaters. CS:GO came with an idea to make the most skilled and trusted players in the community to spectate a "suspect" player to determine if he is cheating or not, called "Overwatch". I must say, this is absolutely brilliant, giving the fact that this system doesn't allow you to know the "suspect" true nicknames or steam account nor the rest of the players in that match. To finish this review, I would like to point out a very nice addon in the game, which is, players created content in the game. CS:GO allows you to create your own: maps, weapon skins, and so on. And lets other players download and use it directly in their game. You can then comment or vote that creation. There are weapon skins that are "paid to get" and doesn't give you any advantage, it's just fashionable. But sometimes the animations are so cool or the colours are so awesome, that Valve decides to put them in Loot boxes with very rare and low drop percentage, so if you get one of these, you can either use it and brag about it, sell to other players, or trade for anything you want with other players. Conclusion: If you enjoyed the Counter-Strike franchise, or love a competitive skilled-oriented FPS, I recommend you give CS:GO a try, if you have the recommended System Requirements. If you're looking for an easy, simple FPS game, don't buy this game. 8/10
game-hours: 33.0
review: Counter-Strike steht fr Bomben- und Geiselrettungsszenarien. Genau das erwarte ich auch von Global Offensive und genau das bietet es auch. Das ist erfreulich, denn so simpel diese beiden Modi verglichen mit Spielarten moderner Shooter heutzutage sind, so taktisch anspruchsvoll und zeitlos gut sind sie auch. Das gilt besonders, wenn man die Karten Fnf gegen Fnf spielt. Interessant ist vor allem Valves Entscheidung, nicht noch weitere Modi auer Waffenrennen und Demolition) hinzuzufgen. Die Entwickler sind sich der Anziehungskraft und Eigenstndigkeit ihrer Modi bewusst und verzichten bewusst auf weiteren Schnickschnack. Das gefllt. Die beiden gerade erwhnten Modi sind nettes Beiwerk, mehr aber auch nicht. Waffenrennen eignet sich sicherlich fr Neulinge, um ein Gefhl fr das Spiel zu bekommen, den eigentlichen Spielablauf spiegelt es aber in keiner Weise wieder. Waffenrennen ist eine witzige Ablenkung, eine Mglichkeit, mal mit mehr als nur den blicherweise im Clanwar verwendeten Waffen zu benutzen. Zum wirklichen Training dient es allerdings kaum. Spa muss trotzdem sein und schon jetzt produziert die Community tolle neue Karten zum Austoben (Einfach nach Maps mit awp_ oder fy_ im Namen suchen!). Neu ist die Mglichkeit, die klassischen Modi im Casual-Stil zu spielen. Hier gibt es keine Geldknappheit und schusssichere Westen gibt's gratis. Diese Vorstufe der Knigsdisziplin (Friendly Fire ist ein Schlsselelement in CS-Gefechten) dient Einsteigern zum ben, zum Besserwerden, zum Herantrauen an die Materie. Veteranen lsst das kalt, die wissen eh, was abgeht. Wenn Kinder nicht hier sein wrden, wrde das Spiel besser sein 7/10

review: The legacy of the original Counter-Strike. It was about time we had a new Counter-Strike able to replace both CS 1.6 and CS:S. I honestly think that Counter-Strike: Global Offensive achieved that, even if the gameplay has been adjusted to the engine, even if the game is more oriented towards casual gamers, even if haters try to hang on to their old relics, talking trash of the game. I love Counter-Strike 1.6, but it's time for a change, and if you've enjoyed CS:1.6 or CS:Source, I strongly suggest you give CS:GO a try. Have an open mind, it's a new game, it will require time to get used to it. Deathmatch, Arms Race, casual mode, competitive mode, all these are built-in modes available by matchmaking. The old server browser is still available, so it's possible to use private servers as well. Ranks have been added to the competitive mode to try to match people of the same level. You can look for a match on your own or with up to 5 people. Most of the weapons are still there, m4, ak47, awp, deagle, etc... The game is updated frequently (every 1 or 2 weeks), and there are enough players to find a match within a minute. There's also an overwatch system to get rid of cheaters as fast as possible. Enjoy !

game-hours: 692.0
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a great game. It's a mix of the first official game Counter-Strike 1.6 and the newer Counter-Strike Source. The Counter Strike series has always gotten inspiration from it's previous iterations. The game has many old school maps like De_Dust 1 and 2, Office, and many other maps that were in the previous games. They added plenty of new maps as well. They added the amazing deathmatch mode from the Counter-Strike dedicated servers that used to only be fan made. The GunGame is also an official game mode now too. They added a competitive mode into the game that lets you play a amazing 5v5, aka the scrim. This gamemode has different levels of difficulty, and it's counted by your skill level. You start out by playing 10 matches with no level, then you earn a level that matches your skill. The game has the old school goods you like, and it adds new things like the Tazer and Molotov that make the game even greater. Something else they added is the great community based hacker finder called Over Watch. If someone reports a player in a server for using hacks, a trusted player that Valve picked for Over Watch is able to see a section of the game footage they were "hacking" in. The person watching determines if they were hacking instead of the usual VAC system that Valve uses. The best thing about it is that the names are all covered and the "Hacker" is called the Victim and the rest of the player names are hidden, making it fair for people worried about getting reported by trolls. If a player is found guilty of using hacks, it doesn't result in a permanent ban. If it's your first time using a hack, you only get a ban of a few days. The ban length increases with each one until the player is banned permanently. The last and most amazing thing they added is being able to watch your matches. Now getting clutches and other amazing kills worth your time because you can go back and show off to your friends, or even use it to make montages and things like that. In conclusion, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is definitely worth the 15 dollars. It's almost like a best of compilation of the Counter Strike series. In my opinion it's even better than Counter-Strike Source. (Thank you for the help Joejoebuckbuck)

You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. game-hours: 1321.5
review: Counter Strike Global Offensive is the latest installment of the Counter Strike series, and in my opinion the best! The ranking system is one of my favorite features from CS:GO, it gives you the ability to play other players in your skill group. You are given a skill group after playing ten matches. Ranging from Silver 1 (The worst of the worst) all the way to Global Elite (aka pros). Having the ranking system also gives me drive to get better and learn techniques for understanding the game better. A downside is that the default MM Valve servers are only 64 tick, which can lead to your bullets not hitting your target when shooting, but this can be solved by paying for the ESEA 128 tick servers which are far superior. The problem I find most frustrating is the cheaters, now I am not the kind of guy that will call cheats if someone gets a 1-click with an ak-47 but I still find that I run into cheaters on a weekly basis, once again though ESEA has little to no cheaters with there anti-cheat software, so if you are willing to pay a small amount towards ESEA you will find that you will have a much more enjoyable expirience. -Chris Rating - 9/10

game-hours: 2733.9
review: A game where skill is the primary gameplay factor. You level-up yourself, not a character or loadout. You learn the maps, the guns, and the techniques... you memorize recoil timing and bullet-spray patterns and try to get the upper hand whenever possible. Players of other shooters might avoid CS:GO because of the steep learning curve: Don't expect to just drop in and kill, you will find yourself drastically out-skilled. Stick around for a while and you might learn that perfect AK-47 control, and to out-strafe enemies or headshot through smoke using the radar... and all the tricks that I've found fun since I bought Counter-Strike: Source in 2006. Don't forget to check out the Community Scene... all the crazy maps or mods like Surf, ZombieMod, and my favorite- GunGame (now called Arms Race, for some reason... perhaps because COD stole the name). My experience with the Counter-Strike series has been nothing but rewarding and addicting, and I never would have gotten a STEAM account without it. Highly recommended.

Overall one of the most funnest and balanced multiplayed FPS's I've ever played. 10/10.

game-hours: 795.1
review: Counter Strike: Global Offensive, or CS:GO, is a fast paced shooter. Most guns do not have a zoom feature so it isn't like call of duty if that is what you are wondering. You have to have a base understading in order to get really good. Now that doesn't mean the game is not fun. There are many game mods for all types of players. They range from rescue the hostage, to plant the bomb, to your basic team deathmatch. There is also a competitive playlist if you are into that hardcore stuff as well. Most of the maps are really well made and don't get old, if you do happen to get old of the standard maps then just buy the $3 map pack, or make a friend that has it since you can just join his lobby and play with em, that gives you this cool badge. This is a great game if you want something you can jump in and have fun.

game-hours: 473.6
review: A world that's dominated by many FPS games, each with their own unique gameplay and style. What sets CS:GO apart from the others? Well CS:GO is extremely detailed with every aspects of the game. This includes gameplay which branches out on to sounds, shadows and visuals, balancing out the map layouts and economy of the weapons, and the weapon mechanics are even accurate as it could ever be, the recoils, hitmarks and damage. Also not only the gameplay is amazing but cleverly valve took a big step into introducing skins. Skins are the main reason why people are now more interested in this game. There is a plethora of skins in this game, arranged in 7 subgroups. - Common (Consumer Grade) - Uncommon (Industrial Grade) - Rare (Mil-Spec) - Mythical (Restricted) - Legendary (Classified) - Ancient (Covert) - Exeedingly Rare (Melee Weapons) In each of these categories it is also in another subgroups of its quality such as: - Battle-Scarred - Well-Worn - Field-Tested - Minimal Wear - Factory New Overall CS:GO stands as a glowing reminder that quality game design is rewarded in longevity and variety. At the end, what matters is not if CS:GO is innovative or more of the same than CS:S, COD, BF but what counts is if it's fun.

game-hours: 55.0

game-hours: 2268.1
review: Coming back after a long hiatus from the CS 1.3-1.5 days, I started playing Source occasionally. After finding some cool people and servers that made the game fun again, I was pulled back into CS and those long gaming sessions. Then I noticed there was a newer version called GO. I didn't really know what to expect from CS:GO but I had to give it a try. At first, it felt very different and I was put off by that. It felt like I was lost in the maps, and that I'd never figure them out because of headshot after headshot. I was dying almost instantly. So I started playing Deathmatch for a few rounds now and then, just to get a feel for the guns and see if I'd get a loot drop. Mainly I stuck to Source. Eventually I started getting pretty good at Deathmatch. I made a few friends and found some regular community servers I enjoyed. From there, the game really began to grow on me. Now I'm enjoying the Competitive mode. Overall, the game no longer feels all that different from Source. The movement and pace is faster, the maps are all familiar but nicely revamped, and the graphics are really good... but at the heart of it, CS:GO is still very much the CS that we all know and love. Going back to Source, now that I'm used to GO, feels very dated and slow. This was a needed update, and one I'm thankful for. CS:GO is an excellent version of our favorite game. If you're still playing Source on a regular basis, you really should consider checking out GO, and not just one or two rounds. Give the game a good shot at winning you over. Like me, I think you'll find that it's the best version yet.

review: CS:GO offers a competitive matchmaking feature - unlike CS:S and CS. This feature also includes a ranking system which I think makes it even more exciting and it's a great way to easily find a match without having to use IRC, etc. In addition they've added molotov and decoy grenades, which I think is great even though I usually just go with the same old 2 flash, 1 nade, 1 smoke. Through recent updates, they added weapon skins and stickers. It basically means that you get to play with dolls as a guy. I think it's decent and it doesn't affect the gameplay in any way. If you were a fan of CS or CS:S, you'll probably like this game. You just gotta get used to it. I've seen many people complain about it at first but they all ended up loving it anyway. So, basically, what I'm saying is; If you liked the previous Counter-Strike games, you should definitely try this out, too. I recommend it.

game-hours: 298.2
review: People ask all the time "What makes this better than CS:Souce? Why should I buy this if I already have Counter Strike?" It's a good question. To be honest, it is, for the most part, the same game. Similar gameplay, Terrorists, Counter Terrorists, bombs, hostages... the whole deal. The graphics are updated, which is nice of course, they added bot AI, which helps to fill up teams when a bunch of people suddenly leave, and there are slight changes in the armory, as there are in each game (Riot Shields in Condition Zero, Molotovs in Global Offensive, etc.), but that's not what sets it apart. My favorite part of CS:GO is the options to help you quickly find a game, of any official gamemode, with actual players in it (and maybe some bots, too). The most agravating part of playing CS:S, CS:CZ, or any other version, is finding servers. "Okay, this one is a map and gamemode I'd like to play! Oh... there's no one here." "Oh look, a server with plenty of people in it! What the hell? Why do I run so fast? What's going on?! What is a "Surf" server?" "Okay, fine. One last server. If this doesn't work, I'm out. Okay, look promising so far... OH FFS! JAILBREAK AGAIN! I'm out." The worst part of this was that I never learned how to actually play Counter Strike! I understood that I needed to shoot the enemy, but I didn't know the strategies for the maps, how well each gun worked, or even where the bombsite really was! But no more! Since getting CS:GO, I've learned to play and actually enjoy Counter Strike! And it's really fun! Like, addictively fun! As in, I have a problem, please separate me from this game so I can focus on the important things! Nevermind, give it back! I wants it... the precious... Anyway, yeah. If you have no problem with playing nothing but community servers, there's no huge advantage to CS:GO. Some different weapons, new maps, some alternate gamemodes (Demolition is like Defuse, but smaller maps and more fast paced. It's really fun, actually!) And it has those Surf and Jailbreak mods in the community servers too, don't worry. If you want to play counterstrike for the sake of counterstrike, get this. If you just want it to play Garry's Mod and you have little interest in actual CS, just get Source. And whichever way you go, Enjoy!

game-hours: 1107.6
review: Say bye to your life already
game-hours: 500.1
review: For my English 101 class i had to write a review of something so i ended up reviewing this game and here is my review hope you enjoy. A series of Counter Strike games have been released in the past and with COunter Strike Global Offensive it has changed first person shooters. With the Creativity of the steam community they continue to change and make the game a new experience each time. Averaging 3.5 million unique players each month new ideas are displayed about every hour each day. This game is meant for people who both like FPS and are completely new to them. Players who are new or kist playing it for fun, the casual section of gameplay allows these players to experience the game on a non-competitive level. The casual section breaks down into four sub sections being deathmatch, arms race, demolition, and casual classic. Deathmatch is the perfect place to play a quick warm up game and allows players to practice using guns that they havent used before. Arms race is just like gun game from other fps games but sets the guns to 27 and it is a quick paced game and really fun if you play with a lot of friends. Demo gives the feeling of casual classic but it only has one bomb site and it is hard to plant before the counter-terrorist are dead or the terrorist are dead plus it has generally small maps. For me this is not the gamemode for me but if you want to play a quick 20-25 minute game without people yelling at you then this a good choice to play. Casual is in my opinion the game type that is most like competitive but again without the ranting and arguing of players when you lose. The couple of things that are annoying is unlike comp it only goes to 15 rounds and you dont switch sides. This does create a somewhat of an unfair game since some maps are sided towards either CT or T. With that being said I think casual is very relaxed and calming without people yelling in the microphone. Now here is where there is a lot of frustration, and annoyance but will always be fun to play. Even though I personally dont think this is the best in the game i do think it is second and a close best feature of the game. There are a lot of takeaways from comp but like any competitive game there are negatives. The competitive game type nevers gets old with different operations coming out every three-four months. Communication is key in this game and with ingame voice there are a lot of negatives but ill get to that. On most days youll get into a game with respectable nice people that dont really get mad and yell. Comp gives every player the rush to want to be the best rank, or the best player in the current lobby. Like all games you can leave midway but in this game it punishes the players to a 15-7day ban from comp. These bans are completely random so it does force people to stay in the game. With Comp it is a 30-90 minute game where it lasts 30 rounds and does switch roles to balance the game. Unlike most FPS CSGO doesnt allow players to aim down sights unless it has a scope and this is where i believe luck and skill comes in and it enhances the gameplay. Players will normally understand if you dont know the callouts on the map and will tend to help some try hard players are not so forgiving. Another great part that i can think of is valve put in chickens that roam around the maps and during the holidays they will add stuff to the chickens. Ex. last week they put in cheers and balloons so each time you killed them those would come out. The chickens can also be used to figure out where the enemies are if one happens to see it killed. The way that the game balances the skill of players is the best, they will put same skill ranks together and dont really allow high ranks to play with the low ranks. With all of the positive ideas there are sadly always negatives. CSGO community consists of people who do try a little too hard and care too much about the game. I have been in games where teammates will constantly yell into the mic just talking trash to each other and it really doesnt help them to do better. Personally i dislike like the little kids that come into the game swearing and commanding the adults on what to do and i know most of my friends feel the same way, they are called Squeakers. At times players that arent good enough to play the game will try to cheat and try to get an advantage over the other players. They will use hacks, such as a wallhack or an aimbot. There are other programs but i am not familiar with them. Also players who have been playing for a while and reached a high rank cant compete with their current rank players so they make a new account and face new people, these are called Smurfs. I know that i am missing a lot of things that people find negative about this game but these are my big negatives. Where all of the creativity in this game comes from is from the workshop and it is so vital to this game. I find this the best feature due to all of the stuff that you can make and it can be used in the game. The developers allowed players to make their own custom skins for the guns in the game and if it gets voted up by the community then it can be added the to the game and you can make money off of it. Right now there are skins that cost 450$ but there are a lot of cheap ones the expensive guns are the knives. Not only can you make skins you can make stickers that can go through the same process to get into the game. People can also make their own maps but i have yet to try that feature but i have seen some nice maps. Valve added crate drops into the game to that contains chances at getting a rare skin for the gun or knife but it can cost 1$ or so for the case and 2.50$ for the keys. I find this gambling system not worth the money so I recommend selling the cases because they do add up each week. I ended up with 25$ from drops and bought copies of the game for two of my friends. With having only 240 hours invested in the game i have seen people with over 2,000 hours so that means that it must be an amazing game for someone to have that much time put into this game.

game-hours: 322.0
review: Love this Counter Strike. Gameplay - It is competitive , fun and includes a range of great weapons and maps that provide hours of fun. Teams - Can play as Counter Terrorists and Terrorists around the world featuring the famous SAS, IDF and other special forces. Community - A great friendly community that play a range of game modes including competitive, demolition, casual and hostage rescue. Great with friends and highly recommend the competitive play. I hope people out there who havent tried any Counter Strikes such as Source or Global Offensive buy both of these great classics and enjoy this truely awesome Valve game. See ya !

game-hours: 826.6
review: Even though I have only played a short amount of time on Counter Strike Global Offencive, I feel as if I can put down a compitent review. At first, I hated this game. That was two years back now, when I had first truly switched over from console gaming to PC gaming. I would comment on how I could never hit anything and how everyone else seemed to have pin point accuracy. This was just ignorance and lack of knowledge of the game, obviously. However, now, things are much different. In the past two week, I have really been putting some time into CS:GO and pushing myself to get better. Unfortunately, I tend to grow angry with game very quickly. Especially first person shooters as I feel that I am good at the genre. Oh, how nieve I was. This game is a real challenge to those who have never touched a Counter Strike game on the PC in their lives. I have played CS:GO on the Xbox 360 and Counter Strike back on the Playstation 2 and thinking I would dominate on the PC too was stupid of me to believe. As I said, the game is a challenge and without the experience, you will be walked over. However, if you are willing to put the time and effort into the game, as I have finally brought myself to doing, you will begin to enjoy the game. Though this can take a great deal of time and you wont be dominating every game like you may do in other first person shooters like Call Of Duty and Battlefield, you will still feel and improvement. And unlike those other games, you will continue to feel like you are improving. Now, I am by no means saying I am good at this game, as I am very unconsistent with my results, sometimes scoring well and sometimes scoring poorly, but my point still stands. Heck, I feel that just playing CS:GO has improved my aim in Battlefield 3 too. Although, I didn't find myself improving at all until I switched the cross hair to "Classic". This is a nice feature as I did find the CS:GO cross hair to be at all useful for me and couldn't hit anything with it. Something I have to note on this game is the crate system. I am still on the fence about this as it seems like a good concept but in practice, especially for me, it falls flat. You unlock the crates by playing each game mode in CS:GO and each grate holes different rewards and one of those rewards is given to you at random. Now, this seems great, you are getting skins for your weapons for simply playing the game. It kept me engaged for a good few hours as I was desperate to bag myself a crate. However, this is were it falls flat for me. All my effort, yes, for a poor crate with little in seems to go to waist when I first find out that I cant actually open the crate without spending money on a key for said crate. This is like a kick in the nuts and a middle finger to the player. I mean, picture this, you have just grinded for a good crate by playing all the game modes over and over and even bought a pass for the events that take place, to then be told you need a key to open something you have worked hard for. It makes no sense and seems like a blatent cash grab from Valve. Even though there is a blatent cash grab by the developers, I still enjoy this game and will continue to play it in the future. I recomend this to anyone whom hasn't played it and wants to get into a competitive multiplayer first person shooter.

game-hours: 49.5
review: As an ex call of duty player this game was more than an average change in tone from your regular fps. Despite not having jaw dropping graphical fidelity and advanced texture tessalation like some of the next gen games do, and not having as many features as other AAA fps games do. CS:GO makes for a unique take and updated version of a mod-born fps franchise that exceeds quailty over quanity. While it may seem lacking in basic things that fps games have become accustomed to like leveling up, you quickly begin to appriciate that GO is a game that wants to stand out as something different. Every different feature gives GO an inch and when you start to add those features and differences together you start to find that CS is slowly taking over the fps stage. 1 inch at at time. For all time fps fans this game will keep you playing until you look at your watch thinking what felt like an hour, turned into six. That's the mark of a great game. Personal rating (my oppinion): 9/10

review: One of the, possibly THE best first person shooter out there. It's not full of un-neccessary animations that you'll find in other titles. The professional scene is outstanding, not as big as other titles like Call of Duty, which alledgedly has pro players, also known as a bunch of teens who trash talk in a game filled with aim assist. Valve never dissapoints, even with some nooks that need improvement, such as the tick rate, it is a title that delivers. The graphics are good. It is one of the most skill based games, and do not try to get good at this game by donating to get some powerful characters. Gunfights, action, tactics, strategy, anything that you would see in a war, this game delivers. I would give this a good rating, as the developers still have to do some work to satisfy some. There is a bit of work needed to perfect this game, and that bit is a point that I will be taking off of my rating. 9/10, would recommend, go out and get it now, if you do not like it, than you do not have the brain for a skill-demanding game. Unlike other developers that have their games die out in a few months, some, even weeks, the community for Counter Strike: Global Offensive keeps rising. Valve do not need to release a stupid sequel like some other publishers and developers do, they know how to satisfy the player, and they do not need so many DLC's that cost as much as the game. I have gone past my point, I think you can tell I am in love with it, I'd like to thank my brother for making me switch to this from the scum that is Call Of Duty.

review: Its a good follow up to the classic Counter-Strike 1.6. Game feels good and have been improved together with the professional teams. The only downside is that you cannot choose region or language and some problems occur as follows. Russians mostly are matched up with english speaking players, and they have overall bad english or no english at all. The Valve servers currently run at 64tickrates/second wich makes the competitive match making abit luck based sometimes. CDkey's are very cheap in Russia and this is a problem when many players abuse it to cheat with a n account. Skins on weapons and knifes are really good and brings some trading into it wich makes the community flourish around this aspect aswell.

review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

review: Revan was only 23 years old. He loved CS:GO so much. He had most of the achievements and items. He prayed to Gaben every night before bed, thanking him for the inventory he's been given. He calls him a console peasant. He slaps him and sends him to sleep. He's crying now and his face hurts. He lays in bed, and it's really cold. He feels a warmth moving towards him. He looks up. game-hours: 195.1
review: In 2002, I played a few games of CS 1.6, which has started and since been remembered as the best FPS i've ever played. (Other than perfect dark, golden eye ETC, thats a different topic.) Then CS:S came along, which I will proudly say today is the best FPS on Steam currently. To counter what others say about it, yeah it has flaws. What game doesn't? Anyways, CS:GO used to be a highly despised game when it came out, and like every game it had issues. I think that most, if not some or all major issues with the game have been ruled out already. Despite a slightly growwing community of hackers in higher ranks, (A problem that ALL and i mean ALL games will have,) which I am not sure can ever be fixxed once it appears. (Kind of like ARMA 2.) I recommend this game not because of a biased opinion, but because it is the only FPS that I can play and actually enjoy it. Sometimes you get matched with people with a lower rank, or don't know the map, but hey, you're that guy sometimes as well. 90/100, That Deagle update.

game-hours: 1107.6
review: Say bye to your life already
game-hours: 500.1
review: For my English 101 class i had to write a review of something so i ended up reviewing this game and here is my review hope you enjoy. A series of Counter Strike games have been released in the past and with COunter Strike Global Offensive it has changed first person shooters. With the Creativity of the steam community they continue to change and make the game a new experience each time. Averaging 3.5 million unique players each month new ideas are displayed about every hour each day. This game is meant for people who both like FPS and are completely new to them. Players who are new or kist playing it for fun, the casual section of gameplay allows these players to experience the game on a non-competitive level. The casual section breaks down into four sub sections being deathmatch, arms race, demolition, and casual classic. Deathmatch is the perfect place to play a quick warm up game and allows players to practice using guns that they havent used before. Arms race is just like gun game from other fps games but sets the guns to 27 and it is a quick paced game and really fun if you play with a lot of friends. Demo gives the feeling of casual classic but it only has one bomb site and it is hard to plant before the counter-terrorist are dead or the terrorist are dead plus it has generally small maps. For me this is not the gamemode for me but if you want to play a quick 20-25 minute game without people yelling at you then this a good choice to play. Casual is in my opinion the game type that is most like competitive but again without the ranting and arguing of players when you lose. The couple of things that are annoying is unlike comp it only goes to 15 rounds and you dont switch sides. This does create a somewhat of an unfair game since some maps are sided towards either CT or T. With that being said I think casual is very relaxed and calming without people yelling in the microphone. Now here is where there is a lot of frustration, and annoyance but will always be fun to play. Even though I personally dont think this is the best in the game i do think it is second and a close best feature of the game. There are a lot of takeaways from comp but like any competitive game there are negatives. The competitive game type nevers gets old with different operations coming out every three-four months. Communication is key in this game and with ingame voice there are a lot of negatives but ill get to that. On most days youll get into a game with respectable nice people that dont really get mad and yell. Comp gives every player the rush to want to be the best rank, or the best player in the current lobby. Like all games you can leave midway but in this game it punishes the players to a 15-7day ban from comp. These bans are completely random so it does force people to stay in the game. With Comp it is a 30-90 minute game where it lasts 30 rounds and does switch roles to balance the game. Unlike most FPS CSGO doesnt allow players to aim down sights unless it has a scope and this is where i believe luck and skill comes in and it enhances the gameplay. Players will normally understand if you dont know the callouts on the map and will tend to help some try hard players are not so forgiving. Another great part that i can think of is valve put in chickens that roam around the maps and during the holidays they will add stuff to the chickens. Ex. last week they put in cheers and balloons so each time you killed them those would come out. The chickens can also be used to figure out where the enemies are if one happens to see it killed. The way that the game balances the skill of players is the best, they will put same skill ranks together and dont really allow high ranks to play with the low ranks. With all of the positive ideas there are sadly always negatives. CSGO community consists of people who do try a little too hard and care too much about the game. I have been in games where teammates will constantly yell into the mic just talking trash to each other and it really doesnt help them to do better. Personally i dislike like the little kids that come into the game swearing and commanding the adults on what to do and i know most of my friends feel the same way, they are called Squeakers. At times players that arent good enough to play the game will try to cheat and try to get an advantage over the other players. They will use hacks, such as a wallhack or an aimbot. There are other programs but i am not familiar with them. Also players who have been playing for a while and reached a high rank cant compete with their current rank players so they make a new account and face new people, these are called Smurfs. I know that i am missing a lot of things that people find negative about this game but these are my big negatives. Where all of the creativity in this game comes from is from the workshop and it is so vital to this game. I find this the best feature due to all of the stuff that you can make and it can be used in the game. The developers allowed players to make their own custom skins for the guns in the game and if it gets voted up by the community then it can be added the to the game and you can make money off of it. Right now there are skins that cost 450$ but there are a lot of cheap ones the expensive guns are the knives. Not only can you make skins you can make stickers that can go through the same process to get into the game. People can also make their own maps but i have yet to try that feature but i have seen some nice maps. Valve added crate drops into the game to that contains chances at getting a rare skin for the gun or knife but it can cost 1$ or so for the case and 2.50$ for the keys. I find this gambling system not worth the money so I recommend selling the cases because they do add up each week. I ended up with 25$ from drops and bought copies of the game for two of my friends. With having only 240 hours invested in the game i have seen people with over 2,000 hours so that means that it must be an amazing game for someone to have that much time put into this game.

game-hours: 167.9
review: This "review" is directed to those who had 1.6 or CS: Source. CS: GO is exactly what a sequel should have been: A user interface and graphics overhaul. There's little gameplay changes. There are some other grenades including an incendiary and a decoy. There's still 4 buttons to move, a button to jump, a button to crouch, and no  with other moves from other modern shooters like health regen or cover system. Move the mouse around and shoot. There's no ironsights  either with the exception of the two weapons in CS 1.6 that did feature the "older version of ironsights", the AUG and Krieg. In this version you actually aim through the sights but it makes sense, right? CS: GO remains an old school FPS. However, because CS: GO is a graphics overhaul, this also means the game levels have much more "noise". It can be hard to distinguish enemies from the background. There's a machmaking system that puts you into a competitive environment with 30 rounds to play, 15 rounds in each side, 5v5. If competitive pressure isn't a thing for you, there's still the casual (and usual) server browsing and quick play button to play some 8v8+ games with tons of money each round and friendly fire and player blocking disabled. For all that is not related to the core of the game, there's some lighter hearted game modes with quicker pace like deathmatchs. As for the in-game economy, all items that can be acquired are for cosmetic purposes only. There is NO item you can add onto your weapon that affects gameplay. It's just all paint jobs and stickers, and a stupidly expensive toy that counts how many kills you have done with your weapon. If anything it just makes your enemies more visible because of that white and orange $47 AWP they're holding.

game-hours: 1303.0
review: Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive, especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore, skill-based first-person shooter, and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If youre a Call of Duty player, youre going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well, despite doing little to push itself beyond what its always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes, and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years. For the uninitiated, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a small-scale, team-based first-person shooter with permanent death. When a counter-terrorist kills a terrorist planting explosives in a classic Defusal match, or a CT escort swallows a sniper round in Hostage Rescue, the victim is dead for good and doesn't respawn until the next round. As such, players on both sides must exercise skill and care. The bomb objective, meanwhile, gives everyone a purpose. Of course matches end when everyone on a team is dead, but a clever and coordinated terrorist team will give the CTs the slip, plant their bomb, and protect the bomb site. Between rounds, everyone spends earned cash on better gear and guns, and the cycle continues.
game-hours: 1228.7
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. This game is one of the best games I have ever played. It combindes the factor of addiction and the factor of fun together, most of the games cannot combined this two features. The game also includes the factor of collections/collecting, means you are able to collect (in this case) skins for your guns, skins for your knives and it is what makes the game in some way competitive and fun. The other factor that makes the game competitive is the "Competitive Mode", the competitive mode provides the fun of playing with your closest friends or complete strangers, create a team, beat the enemy and collecting ranks that shows your gaming skills. With this "Competitive Mode" you can also play in not a competitive mode and play in Community Servers with your friends and not being annoyed of the fact that if you lose you may derank to a lower skill rank. Along with all this in-game servers and competitive matches there is also a grate community of professional players and professional teams who can erange huge and fun "meetings" like Dreamhack and ETS LANs with tons of professional and famous people. I really enjoyed the game and recommend it to who ever reads this.

game-hours: 473.6
review: A world that's dominated by many FPS games, each with their own unique gameplay and style. What sets CS:GO apart from the others? Well CS:GO is extremely detailed with every aspects of the game. This includes gameplay which branches out on to sounds, shadows and visuals, balancing out the map layouts and economy of the weapons, and the weapon mechanics are even accurate as it could ever be, the recoils, hitmarks and damage. Also not only the gameplay is amazing but cleverly valve took a big step into introducing skins. Skins are the main reason why people are now more interested in this game. There is a plethora of skins in this game, arranged in 7 subgroups. - Common (Consumer Grade) - Uncommon (Industrial Grade) - Rare (Mil-Spec) - Mythical (Restricted) - Legendary (Classified) - Ancient (Covert) - Exeedingly Rare (Melee Weapons) In each of these categories it is also in another subgroups of its quality such as: - Battle-Scarred - Well-Worn - Field-Tested - Minimal Wear - Factory New Overall CS:GO stands as a glowing reminder that quality game design is rewarded in longevity and variety. At the end, what matters is not if CS:GO is innovative or more of the same than CS:S, COD, BF but what counts is if it's fun.

review: Great Game! CS:GO will provide hours of fun, I definitely recommend this game!
game-hours: 32.5
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is the next generation in rhythm games. As with many Japanese dance games, it requires a precise timing and a good sense of rhythm. However, this game includes many unique elements to deviate from the regular dancing genre. In this game, you are put into a map with a dance move of your choice, along with your team. The enemy team starts with the same requirements. There are two dance squads: Terrorist (Rappers), and Counter-Terrorist (Popstars). In the gamemode Team Deathmatch, you must dance against as many dancers of the enemy team as you can. As soon as you see an opponent, you are locked into a duel of disco prowess. When this happens, you must immediately start clicking at him/her with your selected dance move until they become out-danced and fall to the ground, exhausted. You must also be careful not to become out-danced yourself. This is the real meat of the game. When you are aimed and dancing at your opponent, you must steady your moves to become precise by either holding SHIFT to slowly (although accurately) dance at your enemy. You can also do a running slide into your dance stunts for bonus precision by pressing CTRL as you engage in your dance-off. This next part is the rhythm segment required to out-dance somebody. While getting groovy using your said dance move, there is a small reticle, or box (we shall call it the "style box"), surrounding your pointer. Your dance moves emnate from you in the direction of somewhere inside the style box. The faster you click, the faster you dance, but it also expands your style box, so you must keep your dance rhythm timed well to maintain good style and overcome your opponents grooviness. This is all the basics of dancing, but there are interesting elements included in the game to make this more interesting. Unlike real life, if you see two people engaged in a dance-off, you may join in at any time you like, to provide effective backup dancing to your teammate and help him/her dominate the opposing side. Careful though, because anybody on the enemy dance squad may do the same to you. With these rules in play, it is not uncommon to find a team grouped together into an effective flash mob to maintain skilled dancing and increase their likelihood of out-dancing the enemy. Extra gamemodes also spice up the gameplay by adding objectives to your dance round. In Demolition mode, the Rappers must plant a boombox on one of two dance floors. The Popstars are not fond of the rappers (or their boomboxes) so the Popstars must turn off the boombox before its music starts playing too loudly. This often ends in the Rappers facing against the Popstars in a dance-off turf war over their boombox. In Team Deathmatch, it's pretty simple: the Popstars and Rappers must out-dance each other in a fair competition. In Hostage, the Rappers have a bad nightclub and are forcing people to listen to their music. It is the Popstars' jobs to rescue them and shimmy their way back out of the nightclub. In Arms Race, everyone competes to become the best dancer as fast as they can. Each time you out-dance someone, you are given a new dance move; and you progress until the dancing gets harder and harder to pull off, until after using every dance, you are given... a kinfe. U den godda stb a bich in da fac 2 win. THE END 6.6/10 recommended... just get it on sale. ..and DON'T buy keys. You can buy operation passes if you must. Also, some people have bionic body parts that let them out-dance almost anyone with uncanny effectiveness. So watch out for them. They cheat. And stuff.

game-hours: 865.8
review: The Good: gameplay and the graphics are fantastic, and unlike many other games in this day and age the community is (surprisingly) not terrible, asside from the occasional rude dude,raging 12 year old, and a guy caught on a bad day. But still landing a sick one shot on a CT's with an AK47 is always amazing! Actualy headshot killing anyone with anything (accept the p90, negev, M242, and some others) is amazing The Bad: Like all games cs go has its flaws, some of which it cannot fix by changing in game mechanics for example. Hackers. Althought cs go has implimented the overwatch system (in which experienced players "overwatch" recorded games, through the vision of the said suspect) the system has helped but is not a permenent solution. One way hackers avoid themselfs from being band is by buying the game again but on a "smurf account." Smurf accounts are TERRIBLE for newer players. For example a higher ranking individual can buy a smurf and go up against less skilled players, this can fusturate new players and derank them. WHICH IS ANOTHER THIS, what the hell is up with the cs go ranking system?! Here is an example i went 43 kills and 13 deaths up against silver IV (I'm a Silver IV atm) and i got deranked since my team lost... IMO the ranking system should be foucused on the individual not the poor teamwork of a team! (all I know is that cs go goes of a ELO system, that is all I know) In all cs go is a great game that could use some work on its ranking system and something to prevent smurfs and hackers more effectively. So yes I would recommend it if your into shooters or just want a addicting game. BE WARNED this game has a IMMENSE learning curve! CS:GO IS TEH BEST NA :P

game-hours: 795.1
review: Counter Strike: Global Offensive, or CS:GO, is a fast paced shooter. Most guns do not have a zoom feature so it isn't like call of duty if that is what you are wondering. You have to have a base understading in order to get really good. Now that doesn't mean the game is not fun. There are many game mods for all types of players. They range from rescue the hostage, to plant the bomb, to your basic team deathmatch. There is also a competitive playlist if you are into that hardcore stuff as well. Most of the maps are really well made and don't get old, if you do happen to get old of the standard maps then just buy the $3 map pack, or make a friend that has it since you can just join his lobby and play with em, that gives you this cool badge. This is a great game if you want something you can jump in and have fun.

game-hours: 1094.9
review: Awesome FPS game to play with your friends online. Pieces of the Counter-Strike formula are dated at this point, but the superb heart and soul of Global Offensive is timeless. Teams are small, guns are lethal, and rounds are short. There's an addictive just-one-more-round quality to it, because there's a constant desire to do better than last time, to earn a satisfying kill, or to win in a new way. Call of Duty and Battlefield vets will wonder why they can't sprint to escape enemy fire or look down the iron sights to improve aim; Counter-Strike players will feel like they walked into their redecorated home. Certain map redesigns will catch hardcore fans off guard, but the changes are for the best -- the underpass choke point in de_dust, for instance, has a new escape route.

game-hours: 173.9
review: When a friend told me there was a game that let players re-enact the well-known modern skirmishes of Dust 2, Nuke and Vertigo, I couldn't believe any game developer would have the audacity to create such turbulent moments in contemporary political history. Valve's Counter Strike: Global Offensive allows people to play through the scenarios the real counter-terrorism squads had to operate in and, for me, it has really been an eye opener. I'd recommend this game to any person who's studying a course based on inter-pol or counter-insurgency history as well as to those who are just into realistic shooter sims. Re-live the intense close-quarter engagements that our trained elites had to go through!

review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is an incredible game. It incorporates many things that made Counter-Strike: Source and the orignal good, as well as delivering a new experience. review: After playing over 190 hours of this game I suppose I'd better give a review for it. review: This game is not for wooden computers : )
game-hours: 26.7
review: First of all, here are my specs 2011 21.5" iMac 2.5GHz Quad Core i5 (I5-2400S) 4GB 1333 MHz 512MB GDDR5 Radeon HD 6750M 500 GB (7200 RPM) Serial ATA (6 Gb/s*) OS X Mavericks 10.9.2 Not that this game is a challenge for any computer, but still, I think it's always nice to know the specs from which the review is written. All graphic options are maxed out. Always a fun game to play, whether it's online or doing challenges with bots. I've played every single CS game and it has always been one of those games that never looses its value, I always come back to it. This one in particular is the best one yet, in my opinion. I never saw CS series to have any sort of spectacular graphics. Even for its time it was nothing special, the whole game was about the game itself. I do think that this is the first game in a series that has some pretty nice graphics, although some object, like cars, are still pretty rough. But the whole atmosphere from weapons to people to majority of surrounding is pretty detailed and nice to look at. It doesn't feel like something you play just to get your score up. With low price to begin with and often sales it's a no-brainer. I was very happy to have a Mac version as well.

game-hours: 1849.0
review: A worthy successor to the Counter-Strike series that's definately worth being played. Featuring easier access to competitive matchmaking than all of its predecessors, getting the real experience is better than before. Even though it has a lot of new features such as said matchmaking, better demo-reviewing, stats or weapon customization, it still follows the old, proven way. The gameplay is a bit different than what one is used to from other FPS titles. It is focussing more on teamwork, communication and individual skill than any other currently played FPS. It has a very direct and clean feel to it and when the basics are mastered, playing this game becomes even better. The graphics aren't top notch, but are still a huge step ahead compared previous Counter-Strike titles. The completely reworked Source Engine powers the game and any bugs that might be encountered are, once pointed out, usually fixed in regular updates. These updates often include new weapon finishes or map pools and usually come out 1-2 times per month. In addition to the reworked Counter-Strike originals, new maps have been added to the map pool that can be played in competitive and casual matchmaking, as well as in the built-in Gungame and Deathmatch variants. Also, there is the map workshop where map creators have a possibility to get their maps out in the open to be reviewed and played. Some of the most played and most liked maps are packed in so called Operations which usually last six months. There have been two of those operations, both featuring unique collectible coins - and more are to come. Overall, a great game that's best played with four friends (or strangers). The visuals and the gameplay might not apply to everyone, but to me it is one of the best games to date. With some work put into deathmatching and improving oneself it will become a great experience. Another plus are the relatively low hardware requirements that allow players with low-end PCs to still play the game. After over 800 hours of gameplay and over 350 competitive matchwins, I can say that this is by far my favorite game of the moment.

game-hours: 100.1
review: One of the finest LAN games Ive played. Expertly crafted and refined and far more accessible to new players than previous incarnations. The new Demolition mode is quick and intense, with smaller maps sporting just one bomb site while plenty of varied cover guarantees exciting firefights. This mode is excellent for new players as everyone is given full armour and a gun at the beginning of each round (starting with the AK/M4). If you get a kill, next round you get a different, typically less versatile, gun for the next round (with grenades being awarded for multiple kills). This auto balances teams excellently as the most effective players have the worse guns while the new players spend longer with the easier ones. Theres the added bonus that when playing with bots, you can take control of them when youre out. All in all, this is the finest CS there is. With smoother, more varied gameplay, better sound and graphics, and a wealth of high quality, free content in the steam workshop. Worth every penny.

game-hours: 18.6
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is one of my favorite games to jerk to. I know most of you would disagree, that other games are better for jerking. But hear me out. First off, why a first-person shooter? (Yes, I realize that to most of you -- OBVIOUSLY first-person shooters are best for jerking. But there are some people who don't realize this, and I think it's only proper to first explain a little). I mean, I'll admit it's kinda weird that some (indeed MANY) of you haven't made the connection. And I'm not looking down on you if you instead jerk to games like DOTA and Pokemon, and not to FPSs. Some people just discover things a little later. And that's okay. Everybody's different. Indeed, maybe now, if you were to load up your favorite FPS, you'd find that you DON'T like jerking to it, and would find yourself turning that game off and loading up something you know you like to jerk to, like Dark Souls. But again, no worries. No one is judging you. Just take comfort in the fact that, one day, or one night, you'll load up a shooter like Rust; you'll remember that it's illegal to shoot people and jerk at the same time, and you'll just FEEL it. Some of us just take longer to grow up. And that's okay. Now that I have addressed the r*t*rds, why Counter-Strike: GO? Why not Call of Duty or Battlefield? Why not jerk to Half-Life? Singleplayer shooters are generally not fast-paced enough. Like, you'll see an enemy, shoot and jerk at it until it dies, and then that battle's over. Maybe some of that enemy's buds will be around, and you'll get more jerking and shooting done at once -- but that's if you're lucky! [An exception is Painkiller and games like it; from a gameplay perspective I think those games are great, but they're a little too BDSM for my tastes (especially Painkiller), and thus they lose to even CoD and Battlefield, IMHO]. So why is CS:GO better than shooters that are similar? Three reasons. 1) Pacing: the sexual tension in those games is constantly ruined. Like, I'll join a server, and find a nice corner or dark spot, and then some air thing will fly in and kill me. In counter-strike, the only flying things are small pieces of metal and fluids. 2) A**h***s: when I hide in a spot away from air units, everyone calls me a camper, and a noob, and a f*g. So this is a personal thing. I don't like moving around with the WASD key and then quickly moving my hand to my genitalia whenever I see an enemy player. I've been injured more than once playing the way everyone else does and just don't like it. And I suspect that in their hearts, most male players don't like it, either, but play like that anyway. And so -- how does Counter-Strike: GO avoid this s problem? It has casual servers full of marijuana-smoking people. And they're so chill that when you "camp," it's okay. They might ask why you're camping, and you can just tell them that you're jerking, and they'll be like, "Oh okay; that's cool, brah." And then they'll ask if you lift, and then play music from the late 80s over their mics. The casual scene in CS:GO understands. They're accepting. 3) Quality of the Guns: Valve's guns are perfect. They are simple and elegant. Sound exciting, and yet are comforting. They are somehow smooth and yet scream passion in a way few game guns do. They are a rarity among guns in gaming; they are perfect guns for touching yourself. So CS:GO is the perfect game, right? Well, not quite. Before I voice my only criticism, I want to point out that I'm a feminist. My father was a very feminist man, and when he would take us camping, we would sing feminist songs, and burn pre-1960s dresses in the campfire. And though my mom was really mean to me and got thirty years in prison, I'm very sensitive to the way men interact with women and what's disrespectful. Now that you know I'm a feminist, just know that, probably because of my upbringing, there's just something I dislike about shooting women and masturbating at the same time. It just comes off as very disrespectful to women. And so when I hear ladies over their mics on Counter-Strike, and I know they're on the other team, I feel anxious. And not in a good, pure, sexual way, but in a shameful way. This may sound sexist -- Why's it okay to shoot guys and jerk the ole sausage, but not do the same to women? -- but the truth is it's just a different, sordid feeling. And it gets even worse when I'm not sure if the female voice belongs to a woman or to a little boy (or worst of all: a little girl!). The thing is, I am 136% against jerking off while shooting children, and I'm sure most of you are, too. The good news is: very few little girls play Counter-Strike: GO. And overall this issue is not a game breaker because half the time the female and underage players are on my team, and I can just jerk and shoot around them. Sound: 8/10 Jerkability: 9/10 Gameplay: 10/10 Writing: 7/10 Graphics: 8/10 Feminism: 5/10 Overall Score: 8/10 Special Note: I accept that the original Left 4 Dead might be the best game for jerking.

review: Very immersive experience. Great visual effects and graphics. Stunning performance when it comes to highly action-packed moments: the game has no stutters whatsoever and always runs smoothly. Neat variety of gamemodes to choose from, along with Competitive matches, which represent a great feature of the game itself. They are complex, yet very understandable, which is good. Only slight drawback is the community, or at least a big part of it. Many people, unfortunately even in Competitive matches, do not show any interest in the game itself by cheating and hacking, or simply by throwing the match and dragging the whole team down. Overall very well made game. All it takes to master it is practice. Everything else is already taken care of.

review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

game-hours: 1355.2
review: There's a lot I could say about CS:GO currently, with the new updates and all. If you're not one for change, stick to CS:S or 1.6, as right now CS:GO now has a market system which many older players find horrible. I personally like it, because it's optional. Yes, Valve will try to force it on you with crate drops and collections, yet the base game is of course amazing. They've added in a fair number of new weapons, for example, the PP-Bizon replaces the MP5 and the M4A4 (and the M4A1-S stock weapon) replaces the regular M4A1 Maverick. Scopes on AUGs and SIGs have been updated, and grenades can be thrown underhand. Also, aiming with respect to movement has changed. Recoil patterns are now slightly random. Looking past all of the changes and adapting would be for the best, seeing as how right now this is the most played version of the series. Old players will find their way on their own, and eventually either keep playing casually on a (non-valve) server or they can use the Classic Competitive gamemode to participate in a pick-up game, or they can get their friends and participate in a scrim, which is really fun. New players are able to of course play casually and try to pick up on the game, as it's easier than ever with official servers. And I think old and new players alike are able to enjoy the skins in the game (just don't open too many crates if you play other games/have other hobbies). All in all, this version of Counter-Strike may NOT be the best in the series. In my opinion, it is because I am used to the changes from Source and 1.6. It's really up for the player to decide whether if they want to play this or not. It's still great, and even better with friends, but if you're still a regular on a server on CS:S or 1.6, you may want to just stay there. However, if you see this game for half-off or even 75% off like in the Winter Sale last year, I highly recommend it. One more thing--- if you don't FPS, I really wouldn't buy this.
game-hours: 1387.9
review: This game is a very good fps I like how there is ranks and such.
game-hours: 367.8
review: Has a doge sticker for your gun. 10/10 would shrek again.
game-hours: 590.4
review: A much-refined first person shooter which recieves frequent balancing updates. While easier to get into than other competitive games (Such as DOTA 2), the community can still be harsh if you underperform in the competitive mode (Which comes with a decent, but not-yet-perfect ranking system). It features a few game modes appealing to all skill levels, and custom made privately run servers as well as officially run Valve servers. All in all, I have very much enjoyed my time playing the game, and definitely got my money's worth preordering it. As an added bonus, it features a very active community market, where you can sell and buy weapon skins and stickers. If you play your cards right, you can easily make back the money you spent on this game (especially if you buy it during a sale) in steam wallet funds.

review: As an ex call of duty player this game was more than an average change in tone from your regular fps. Despite not having jaw dropping graphical fidelity and advanced texture tessalation like some of the next gen games do, and not having as many features as other AAA fps games do. CS:GO makes for a unique take and updated version of a mod-born fps franchise that exceeds quailty over quanity. While it may seem lacking in basic things that fps games have become accustomed to like leveling up, you quickly begin to appriciate that GO is a game that wants to stand out as something different. Every different feature gives GO an inch and when you start to add those features and differences together you start to find that CS is slowly taking over the fps stage. 1 inch at at time. For all time fps fans this game will keep you playing until you look at your watch thinking what felt like an hour, turned into six. That's the mark of a great game. Personal rating (my oppinion): 9/10

game-hours: 212.9
review: I never played counterstrike until I got CSGO on sale last year. I am now just getting into competative matchmaking and I have to say that this is a hard but really rewarding and in-depth game. The weapons are much harder to master compared to other FPS I have played and ammo is very limited, so this game forces you to think about what you are doing and about your movement and positioning. The game encourages quick thinking but patient, smart play rather than running around like a numpty and spaming your gun at the enemy. The matchmaking system is a great feature. Although I have had a couple of stacked games so far the level of rage, trolling and noobstomping that is endemic in the L4D2 versus community doesn't seem to be a problem in CSGO matchmaking.
game-hours: 169.0
review: I Personally love CS:GO. After 72 Hours of playing this game I can say 3 things, The M16-Silenced (Counter-Terrorist) Is way overpowered and the MP9 and Dual Berettas just plain out suck. I like how realistic the maps are and the ways you can go to get to your objective or the enemy spawn are just amazing. If you are playing in 1920x1080p (Like Me) you are in for a realistic gaming experience. This realistic experience can also be achieved in 1600x900p but you will sometimes see a little bit of pixels on far-away objects, and this can be solved by highing your Filtering in the options to (4x). The way the objects are placed around the map, wether it being a paint can or a televion is just so natural and makes you feel like you are there and you can connect to the way the objects are placed. For example a bunch of buckets and utencils scattered all over the ground may make you think of the chores you might have to do in 30 minutes or so. Some maps like Mirage, have a tunnel (or more) you can travel through to flank or surprise your enemy causing well-deserved laughter and adrenialine. Please buy this game! Thanks :agathacross: Popins :agathacross:
game-hours: 515.7
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a brilliant for the avid competitive and casual gamer. The competitive mode is for those who want to play ranked games against players of a similar skill level and location in the world. It is in a 5v5, first to 16 format, where 15 on 15 is a tie and rematches can be voted on. However, it is my preference to play ESEA, due to the amount of hackers on the competitive games. The casual mode is for players to relax in a 10v10 gamestyle where a Defusal or Hostage Rescue mission can be played. It is greak for players who are starting out or want to warm up before their competitive game. Players can also play on Community ran servers, these could be; Aim Maps, Deathmatches, Clan Practice Server or anything you want. The game runs smoothly on a basic PC, and runs excellently on a top-range gaming PC. The addition of the Arms Deal update has added an extra sense of depth into the game, and allows for players to trade items and make money buy selling their unlocked / dropped items on the Community Market.

review: In 2002, I played a few games of CS 1.6, which has started and since been remembered as the best FPS i've ever played. (Other than perfect dark, golden eye ETC, thats a different topic.) Then CS:S came along, which I will proudly say today is the best FPS on Steam currently. To counter what others say about it, yeah it has flaws. What game doesn't? Anyways, CS:GO used to be a highly despised game when it came out, and like every game it had issues. I think that most, if not some or all major issues with the game have been ruled out already. Despite a slightly growwing community of hackers in higher ranks, (A problem that ALL and i mean ALL games will have,) which I am not sure can ever be fixxed once it appears. (Kind of like ARMA 2.) I recommend this game not because of a biased opinion, but because it is the only FPS that I can play and actually enjoy it. Sometimes you get matched with people with a lower rank, or don't know the map, but hey, you're that guy sometimes as well. 90/100, That Deagle update.

game-hours: 1528.2
review: CS:GO Is a fast paced fps that takes skill and strategy (unlike cod where u just spray your heart out and no matter what u do u will hit someone) It takes imense skill to learn how to control your weapon's spray patterns and get those very crucial headshots. CS:GO is the closest anyone has gotten to the perfect fps, hell it could even be the perfect fps, the game is all about self progression and pushing yourself to be better then u were the match before, learn about ur mistakes, control ur gun and most importantly kill the other team! The game isnt about unlocking guns and huge as scopes and all of that crap, it cuts strate to the chase ( you all have the same pool of weapons, they, theres nothing in the game that can give you an advantage exept yourself) CS:GO provides more than just better graphics than its previous versions, it provides a variety of game modes that everyone can have fun in, more guns, and of course more nades. It is also a very balanced game in which there are no cheat guns and if you die it was probably your fault or u just got caught at close range with a sniper, but that said you should be able to kill your opponent at close range with your sniper if your good enough. There are still some things that CS:GO might have to improve on, but these things are things that all fps games suffer from such as campers and hackers, that nothing valve can do will stop them, ussually there are no hackers in your game, it is very rare for u to come by one if u play on official servers because of the vac (valve anti cheat) program. In all CS:GO has fun updates, great gameplay, and gorgeous gun skins haha! If your looking for an fps to buy this is the only choice you really have because of how amazing it is.

game-hours: 827.1
review: 9.2/10 This game is perfect for any person that calls themself a PC gamer... The different skills you have to master to complete this game, are vast. You cannot get good at this game, by playing for a day, a week, or even months! You must be willing to work as a team, while not exposing yourself at the same time; you must practice the aiming technique over time; and you must learn the maps you play. While this is not an easy game, and I cannot even call myself "Good" I've learned to enjoy losing and passing it off as a learning oppertunity, nobody has a perfect profile on this, nobody can always win. Most often when you die, you learn a new sniping location, or shows you a different way to use your favorite gun. Playing competitive can be exactly as the name suggests, but mainly you accept the win or loss and thank the opposing team for the good game, you may get worked up, but after the game you will calm down and start thinking about how to improve your tecnique. A hard game at the best of times, but enjoyable nonetheless.
