game-hours: 657.8
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a very fun and competitive first person shooter. However, it is very much different from the other mainstream games in the industry such as Call of Duty and Battlefield. Mainly so, the aiming and recoil. Unless it is a sniper, AUG, or SG553, there are no sights to aim down of any kind. But to compensate, there is recoil, which is in a predictable and learnable pattern. All in all this is probably my favorite FPS, and by far the most tactical I've ever played. I would not trade any second I've spent playing it. Not to mention that the community is for the most part very mature and mild mannered, although you will run into the occasional "dbag" and "troll" you more often than not will meet very level-headed people who are looking for fun, and competition. 10/10, Fantastic game!

review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

game-hours: 749.7
review: CHEAP GAME GET IT ASAP.
game-hours: 215.2
review: Are YOU ready to take on the role of either an elite counter-terrorist force or menacing threat to the society? PROBABLY NOT! This game is way too hard to just 'be ready for'. You need to prepare for this. Before you hit that buy button, think very carefully. Are you emotionally ready to get your  kicked time and time again? Are you ready to take control of guns with more recoil than a jackhammer? Are you ready to take on opponents who would actually be worse if they used an aimbot? If the answer to any of those questions is no, this is not for you. If the answer is yes, then read right on my friend. The primary reason to play this is, for me, the realism. In real life you don't respawn, guns have a kick, and tactics are important, and CS:GO knows that. They managed to forge a game where all those are implemented, and that makes for dependance on good tactics above good aim. If you manage to surprise your opponent, you are sure to kill him. This can be done by taking one of the many routes around your enemy while he is engaged in combat with a teammate, or by firing, then sneaking out of sight and hiding in a place he won't expect you. From then on it's an easy kill. You just need to make sure you get there without your opponent knowing. Also, there is aim. Altough deception is the best weapon, sometimes you just need to face each other. There's no way around that. When that happens you need quick reflexes and good knowledge of your gun to quickly dispose of the threat. Before playing even Competitive Casual (the classic no-respawn face-off but with free armor) or Demolition (the classic with awarded weapons), I suggest playing a few matches of Arms Race (Gun Game) to get a feel for the weapons, and then a few matches of Deathmatch (free respawns) to get a better feel for the recoil on your favorite guns. You don't have to master it to get kills, just make sure that the bullets are going forward and not up. Once you've done that, you can get into Casual Competetive and learn the maps by seeing what your buds are doing. The very best way to learn is simply by spectating your team's best player after you've died. I cannot tell you how much he has learned me already. This game has the best gun skins too. Because guns are so realistic the skins have some weight to them, and it gives you a reason not to quit after losing eight matches consecutively. Playing and getting kills with your favorite gun feels awesome. Actually, getting kills in this game is already the most satisfying thing ever, but when it's done with your baby it gets even cooler. The only thing there's not to like about these guns is the fact that snipers exist, but you'll figure that out for yourself soon enough after buying. I figured out how bad snipers were right after booting up CS:S for the first time. I was still loading up when the screen flickered, and I still don't know why, but I got a picture of a man with an AWP jammed down his throat stuck in my head. The barrel was portruding from his belly and blood and intestines lay spread over the sand in Dust_II. I couldn't shake it for the remainder of the loading screen, but I figured out what it meant right after starting my first game. It still haunts me today... Anyway, don't let horror stories like this one frighten you, I'm sure it was just me... BUYBUYBUBYBUYBUYBUYBUYBYUBYUBYUBYUBYUBYUYBUYBUYBUYBUYBUY
game-hours: 741.4

Zastanawiasz si jak przez 350h masz zabija? A n od czego masz onierzu? Karaj noobw w przeciwnym teamie jak rwnie w swoim zajebistym noem ;) Generalnie karaj kadego tym noem kto ci stani na drodze. Przeciwnika, przyjaciela, kurczaka, bomb, flashe, smokegrenady a nawet hegrande. Kupujesz defuse? Nie jeste SAMCEM ALFA. game-hours: 715.3
review: The walls and pillars are alive in this stellar player vs latency experience. Join our hero "the awp" in his single player mission to destroy all living creatures in a 10 mile radius instantly, before he is visable. The real key to this game is to make sure to never at any point activate your Cortex, or any other part of the brain that could inhibit your ability to jam a or d in alternating ways, while violently thrashing your mouse around horizontally. With new-player friendly weapons like the "p90" and the "auto sniper", you are assured that even your 1 eyed pet monkey with a learning disability will still be able to pick up kills. But watch out for anyone with above 100 ping, as they are able to activate the secret "Time-Lord" passive which allows them to play their client in the past, present, and future. Because of this, the omnipotent "Time-Lords" also known as "Brazilians" are able to bend matter and the universe to their will, allowing them to accomplish their round the corner headshots, and invisible peeks. Which adds an exciting new aspect to the game! So if you are ready to get in there and die defusing bombs for your teammates as they tactically clear the wrong bombsite on the opposite side of the map, or be manipulated by the all powerful diety known as "interp", then this is the game for you!

review: After a while of playing cs:go I can talk about many good things in this game but also a few bad aspects that can kill the fun you could have with this game. But theres a much bigger Problem the Wintersale was great no question but a price reduced Counter-Strike part is more hurting the game cause these days I had seen many cheaters and a very bad working Anti-Cheat-Solution the VAC isnt bad. game-hours: 1319.3
review: Me and first person shooters have had a love hate relationship for a very long time, starting out on halo and competing in a few tourneys in it started my descent into it, though after Halo 3's release I felt sort of let down by the genre, attempting to move over to the Call of Duty franchise left me feeling bored with easy gameplay, and constant hands grabbing at my wallet which made me leave FPS in general Then a few months ago I build my first PC looking around during the steam sale for stuff I found the Valve complete pack which had L4D2 and Portal, which I knew and love, aswell as half life which I had yet to try one night when bored I noticed this game in my library and was like, hmmm I wonder what this is I have not returned from that moment, this game has had me so in love, more so then my early days in Halo it is proof for me that graphic fidelity is not the be all end all, the mechanics in this game make it one of the most intense games I have ever played that moment where you start defusing, you hear someone behind you and turn and get that quick lucky headshot, then turn back and start defusing again, as the beeping gets faster and you feel your heart racing hoping that you dont see that green light that marks your demise No matter how many times I have had this moment it has not lost a cent of its love and intensity from me As I said earlier it is not the most visually pleasing, if your looking for over the top visuals, go elsewhere however if you want a well constructed game that runs silky smooth on 90% of machines, and will challenge you to get better. A game where Skill conquers nearly all besides raw luck on rare occasions a game that you dont just pick your favorite gun and keep spawning in with it, where each round your paying to get that gun off of your past performance from the last rounds, and you have to decide, do I just not buy anything or do I get a sub par gun in an attempt to get some real kills CS GO forces you to think smart you cant just walk and spray in a straight line, there is recoil, and there are true tactics here that cater to the well prepared and well coordinated there are also casual modes, which I have little interest in, I play them when I havent played in a few days and want to get myself back in gear before moving back into Competitive I really do enjoy the community market place on here, I have spent way to much on gun skins, but there is absolutely no pressure to buy anything, however I feel its nice to have a gun and name it once in a while and be like "THIS, this is mine" I hope more people get in on this game, especially at this price there is almost no reason not too, I have sold guns on this game for over $60 which then got me a whole bunch of other cheaper gun skins and a game or two this is by far my favorite first person shooter

game-hours: 1302.4
review: The great CS saga continues with CS:GO. A good upgrade from 1.6, with maps being a little bit tweaked with in a goal to balance maps to be less one-team-sided. It is different from CS 1.6 (some people still prefer 1.6 by the way), but it's not similar a tiny bit to any other modern multiplayer-shooters like Call Of Duty series and Ghost Recon:Phantoms. CS:GO is a game that requires the most skill of all multiplayer modern shooters, and teamplay can be as hard as it is fun sometimes, and that is what makes this game so good. It's not just about shooting people. It's a lot more about movement, planning, patience, and timing. One thing i do have a problem with however, is not a big deal (not a thing that happens all that often), is a certain hand grenade scenario. Whenever you run, and you get hit DIRECTLY by opponent's hand grenade (HE, Flashbang, Smoke, Decoy), you actually get blocked by the grenade and it distracts you from moving for a precious 0.5-1.0 sec. There is some argument for it to stay that way. I reckon if you get hit in real life like that, you wouldn't just go on like nothing happened, but the whole thing feels glitchy. It's a thing that should be fixed.

review: Nothing quite like CS:GO; you play well in competitive, you're an aimbotter/ wallhacker; you play poorly, or have fun, or tell a bad teammate he's bad, or get paired up with a 4-stack while soloing, guarenteed you get kicked and get a 7 day matchmaking ban. Beyond that every time this game goes on sale, all the Overwatch work was for nothing, since you get flooded with hackers, smurf accounts, and noobs. This could probably be solved by IP banning/ MAC address banning, but someone was too lazy to implement a real fix so we just get more long drawn out PSAs from Valve about integrity and honor. game-hours: 377.4
review: If you'd compare this game with almost any other FPS you'd see that teamwork is really important in this game. Competitive play they added in CS:GO is great, it allows you to increase your rank level (or lose it). The best thing in CS:GO are the drops. Skins for weapons are really awesome, some of them at least. And then there is Operation Payback, it allows you to play Casual on Custom maps and increase your Payback coin level (Bronze, Silver, Gold). Then there is another good mod, Arms race. In this mod you have to kill 26 players, all with different weapons, and last the first one to get the kill with knife wins the round.

review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive delivers something rarely seen in modern shooters. It brings us back to a time of simpler multiplayer action. In this war, you don't need to call in screaming jets, there are no pointless tchotchkes to unlock, and a stray bullet could mean plotting your revenge for minutes rather than seconds. Modern shooters do their job well, but Counter-Strike is the series that helped build the scene. At 1O euros, Global Offensive is a great extension to that legacy.

review: This game is great and one of the best first person shooters of its generation. The feeling of being the last one on your team has not been replicated in any other game I have ever played and the feeling of winning against skilled opponents is unrivaled. It happens to be one of those games that seems to never get old.

game-hours: 8.9
review: a
game-hours: 794.1
review: Introduction: Well, I play Counter-Strike for quite a while now. It all started for me with Counter-Strike 1.4. (Yes there was a time before Counter-Strike : Source, and yes even a time before Counter-Strike 1.6 AND a time before even Steam was released) My journey with Counter-Strike began with a small Lan-Party with 6 people in a small room at a friends parents house, I played it for the first time and had almost no idea what to do. The bomb is ticking? oh well, who cares? I got the bomb? oh well, who cares? I gotta shoot! And as you might guess, I sucked a lot. I was the epitome of a "NEWB" , "NOOB", "BOON", "NAP" and so on... But after a few hours I thought well I might get it... I kept playing this game after the LAN, started playing online and joined this HUGE Community, with some friendly people and .. a lot of not so friendly people.. But ey, Counter-Strike was BOOMING at that time. After a few months I joined my first Clan, I started Clanwars and kept getting better. I joined the Electronic Sports League - Europe (ESL.EU) and started to join more professionell Competitions (LIKE EAS FIRST DEVISION, Tournaments...) Than there was STEAM and 1.6 released, at the beginning of STEAM... oh God.. PEOPLE DID HATE IT (me too), there were so much troubles with Starting the Game (cause of the Steam Server) problems with the Client side of Steam, problems with Server lists.. list goes on and on. But there were always updates and improvements on Steam.. Anyways today I love Steam, and I love Counter-Strike 1.6. The jump from 1.5 to 1.6 wasn't that much big of a deal, it felt the same. (cl_weather 0) So I kept playing in the EAS / ESL / Tournaments / LAN Events... and it was just fine for years. Then there was Half Life 2 and Counter-Strike : Source comming.. jesus we all were so excited for it, the developer Team of CS:S said that they would change nothing but the graphics and so we thought YES THAT'S WHAT WE WANT! We did want the same freaking hot game just with better graphics, nothing changed on the gameplay and stuff. Same boxes on the maps, same spots on the maps and that's what they promised us.. But when we started playing it... We all knew after a few minutes that's it not even close to the feeling that CS 1.6 gave us.. the aiming was much easier, all of the sudden everyone on the server did a bunch of headshots, even with the DEAGLE, and they even did not had to aim, they could run and while they are running just keep shooting and somehow make some luck shots... So CS:S was never an option for us to play on a professionell level and after a while most of the professionell Clans kept playing CS 1.6. and now a few years later here is Counter-Strike : Global Offensive So when you start the Game you get a completely new Menu. (That looks OK) You get Match Making System, which is also completely new to the Counter Strike Universe, you can go on a Competetive Match Making and do a 5on5 Match just like in the leagues with penaltys for players who Teamattack, Teamkill or just leave the game. Which is quite a good thing, that's still needs a little improvement. It kinda sucks if you got 1 or 2 obvious cheater in the game that run with a speedhack over the map or an aimbot with a 99.9% headshot ratio and you have to play this game to the end. But the guys behind the game are working on that! Now there is this cool Feature Overwatch where some Players of the Community (chosen by some criteria like how long does he play, how often does he play, how is his reputation and so on) can watch gameplays of suspicious players and decide whether they think this guy is cheating or not. If the most part of the Overwatch stuff thinks he's cheating he'll get a ban. Gameplay: Well it feels for me and most of my friends more like Counter-Strike again, not really that exact same feeling like in 1.6 but it's the closest shot! They improved the weapon behavior, they made it a little bit harder to do Headshots and they improved the game sounds a little bit. You got 2 more Game modes, named Arms Race and Demolition that are really cool for a short side trip after hours of Classic Competetive Matches. It makes fun even though it's sometimes kinda hard to spot the enemy on some maps with all this particles and stuff that are flying around, and view sometimes feels for me a little bit cloudy, diffuse I don't know. Result Well we will never get that 1.6 again where it's most of the part really just about skill and aiming. But with GO we have a really fun game to play maybe even on a professionell level, but they need to fix a few things like the P90 is way too strong and almost every "NEWB" can archive a lot of easy kills with that. the DEAGLE is spraying TOO MUCH! After the first shot all other shots are flying anywhere but not near the position you're aiming at. You still sometimes can run and shoot and do some headshots (even on distance) which needs to be fixed (in my opinion) But all in all CS:GO is on a really good way to become the closest thing to the fun CS 1.6 gave us. So I can recommend this game to you guys. have fun.

review: One of the best games I have played. This is one of the first games I have played on my PC, ever since I joined Steam. There are so many things to do to pass time in the game, such as Surfing. Competitive is one my favorite things about the game, it allows for team communication and co-ordination. Also, opening cases have been the death of me, I have opened at least 50 of cases and nothing good, but that wont't stop me from opening them and getting the infamous Butterfly Knife. This game helped me get better at PC games as I was a COD player on console. This game will never get old, and I'll never stop playing it. On the other hand, it does have problems in the community such as Smurfs and hackers, but hopefully, they will try and remove this to keep the game fair. Furthermore, this is the most played game I have on my Library. I would definitely recommend this to anyone whether they are good at FPS or starting on PC games. This game gets 10/10 on my book.

game-hours: 248.5
review: For all the long-time players and fans of Counter-Strike, the newest installment of Global Offensive will surely put your joy meter soaring up to the sky. Generally speaking, Global Offensive (CSGO) manages to implement tournament-like gameplay than previous Counter-Strike series. In it, Valve combining live matches features, so we can watch tournament live streaming; the other features is major updates from previous gamemodes, where now we have multiple sets of tourney-like rules in a map, which inline with the - on my opinion - way Valve want this game to be : as an e-sports game. "Before we go further, I would like to talk about Valve wants to bring CSGO as "e-sports qualified game", which in my opinion, are becoming like Dota 2 which massively supported by Steam to generate revenue via tournaments that they really put a big budget on it. As example is how Dota 2 has "The International", annual prime Dota 2 e-sports competition. By that, if you are CS fans in particular or FPS lover in general that wishes to play a game that might gets you onto a tournament, this is it. Intergrated match streaming, community geared towards tournament, mode rules to cater for competitive play and sportsmanship, player stats to track your progress, all in all to support the Valve and Steam goal to - once again, my opinion - put forth CSGO as sweet candy to collect professional team and put them into tournament (to get them more money, of course :) But hey, thats on positive word :) Besides, those who join the tourney does gets their gaming career even more further than before). Alright, now you know how ambitious Steam and Valve is to make CSGO an e-sports game and setting their own e-sports event, but paragraph below will talk about the CORE of why CSGO differs (or maybe not) from previous installment. So, take the tourney world and put it somewhere first, I'm not gonna review that further." On to the top of the ocean, CSGO does have increment over its previous series, especially the engine they uses. I'm not really expert at it, but it does makes the game more or no less better than CS:Source. Of course, that means new maps, overhauled old famous maps for newer engine, some new weapons and equipments (but also removing certain old weapons that's been present on previous CS series), kinda-new gameplay mechanics, new features like supported by Steam Market which you can buy and sell weapon skins, new "training" mode to play all available game modes in CSGO, achievements expanded, inventory system tied with the Steam Market to uses and keep your weapon skins, and more. Now, to talk deeper about the relations of Steam Market, in CSGO we can get drop loots at the end of the round, which could be a weapon or a case (you need key to unlock it) and you could sell it via Steam inventory to gain Steam Wallet money. Then newer this and newer that, it's just that CSGO is newer and improved. Sounds like a good next-gen CS game, eh? Because it is. Now, because they uses newer engine than CSS, it obviously has certain differences from CSS gameplay. One example is how the recoil works and player movement. It's now different, unlike CSS. Does it bad? Well, for me, I don't find anything bad about it, but on normal game I couldn't find any difference of it. Now, if you play on modded server like playing surf game, you will feel it different. Same with the weapon's recoil and it's relation with player movement. For the recoil, it's now more like a modern shooters, which more realistic than CSS recoil. Also, for the AUG and SSG552, we can aiming down the sight rather than simply "zoomed in", and it has more crosshair sway if you move your character. It makes it harder to land headshots, but its more easier to score body hit. Not saying that doing headshot is impossible, only harder to be compared to CSS and CS1.6. On the environment, it has more interactivity with ingame props and things. For novelty purposes, it's nice. like now the chickens are life-like, you can chase them around, and by that if you play normal game and spot a chicken running away from behind that wall, you know there's something fishy behind it :) All in all, CSGO is a nice to have if you love CS series, and more if you are looking for it's competitive play. But again, CSS is still fun to play, offers more flexibility on mods or custom skins, custom maps to play, and more. Both has it's own strong point, in which CSS still geared towards basic FPS, if you looking for FPS gameplay - or towards fun play, if you play on modded server while CSGO are geared towards competitive play, with little to custom mod your skins and things like that, and supported with multitudes of competitive-ness features. Both are good at different points, and by that I can recommended it for you guys. +1 for the game! *Of course, it's spec requirements also higher than CSS :) Don't worry, if your PC could handle CSS, it could handle CSGO. Don't worry about it. --- Edited for typo... plenty of them =_=

You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. game-hours: 482.3
review: Ahh... One of my favorite games. I was never in to CS, I bought CS:S for the Garry's Mod content. And whenever I tried to play it, I would get destroyed, even by bots. I do admit I was terrible at the game, but it really never appealed to me. The day that I got CSGO I went into it with the same mentallity, and opened up a match of office with easy bots. Instantly I noticed the updated graphics, and it looks good to this day. I ran around for a bit and fired off a couple shots with my pistol, then a bot came to try and ruin my day. I fired at him rapidly with my handgun, and he actually died. If that would of been CS:S, my brain would of been merged with the wall and I would of been looking at the bots on my team walk into walls. Suprised with myself, I carried on and made it to the second round alive. I opened up the buy menu, to find out the MP5 had been replaced (rip neva 4get) with the MP7. I bought it and looked for some bots to murder, I managed to kill 2 of them before getting shot in the back with a shotgun. While I groaned at myself for dying and having to wait for the remaining bots to duke it out, I noticed that you could take control of the bots and play as them. I was very happy with this feature at the time, and I am still happy with it now. After getting used to the recoil and spray patterns, I saw a gametype called competive, and I applied to a match of it. It was on de_dust2, and I got a couple of kills by luck with my trusty MP7. I was amazed by how noob friendly the game was, and how it had matched me with people of similar skill levels. After that match, I decided to go again. And again. And again. If you are looking to get into a competive shooter that is mostly* skill based. get this game. Also it can go for really cheap in sales. Thanks for reading. -Pyro *the p90 exists

game-hours: 1258.7
review: This front section is for old CS players that are skeptical of GO. Many 1.6 and Source fans say that GO is so different, and awful, and stupid and pointless. That is not the case, the changes that have been made since Source have improved gameplay and map balance, and the new weapons such as the Scar, aree good editions. It plays like the old games, the mehcanics and feel to the game are essentially the same. Now if you've never played a CS game before, it should scare you. Not necessarily in a bad way, but Counter Strike is arguably the most hardcore and unforgiving FPS in the histroy of online FPS. That being said, it's also one of the most rewarding. After you get past the steep learning curve, you'll start to love it more and more! I just hit 200 hours and now, it's my favorite online FPS! It's not the run and gun style of gameplay like CoD, it's more the tactical approach. You can't just run around and get kills, you have to understand the mechanics and learn how the game works. Once you've mastered the weapons and nade spots, this is probably the best Competitive FPS you can play!

game-hours: 606.9
review: This game has it's positive points and negative points. It's one of the best competitive games on the PC in my oppinion though. It feels great when you play, it's made on quite an old engine, so a lot of pc's can run it. I could even run it with my old laptop on a smooth 60+ fps. Matchmaking requires a lot of skill, which is why they added skill groups to the game just to prevent you matching with/against people who're not equally skilled as you're. I like a lot about the MM system but there's still a lot to improve. As a lot of the CS:GO players know if they've been playing for a long time, there's a lot of cheaters and smurfs in both lower skillgroups as in Global Elite (Highest skillgroup in the game). This makes people rage and quit matchmaking and search for alternatives like FaceIt, ESEA, CEVO etc.. I wish CS:GO/Valve made their VAC system as good as the one on ESEA, this'll make the game more enjoyable. Overall, I really do like this game and it's definetly a game I would recommend.

game-hours: 776.7
review: In 2005, I crawled out of Counter-Strikes wretched  to become the man I am today. And, now, Im rating the game. How does one even rate his mother? At 8 years old, I would wake up for school at 6:30 AM, but then I started getting up at 5:30 just to get a couple rounds in before class. Call it dedication or a sickening obsession, but I was hooked on CS. It was more than a game. It was my social hub, and my entryway to FPS games. It is and remains the standout multiplayer shooter that paved the way for things to come with Call of Duty and Battlefield. Being eleven years since the excellent Source remake, which I started on, Valve has decided its time to give the game another facelift. What started as a Source port for consoles became a more ambitious project that included PC. While there are no radical departures in Global Offensive, it is without a doubt a reboot. Valve has just hit the reset button on the series, once again. There is no denying that Counter-Strike remains an addictive and rewarding competitive shooter like no other. The game is a hallmark of excellence. There may be flaws, but they are negligible and won't cause massive damage to what is a supreme title. A Masterpiece.

game-hours: 215.2
review: Are YOU ready to take on the role of either an elite counter-terrorist force or menacing threat to the society? PROBABLY NOT! This game is way too hard to just 'be ready for'. You need to prepare for this. Before you hit that buy button, think very carefully. Are you emotionally ready to get your  kicked time and time again? Are you ready to take control of guns with more recoil than a jackhammer? Are you ready to take on opponents who would actually be worse if they used an aimbot? If the answer to any of those questions is no, this is not for you. If the answer is yes, then read right on my friend. The primary reason to play this is, for me, the realism. In real life you don't respawn, guns have a kick, and tactics are important, and CS:GO knows that. They managed to forge a game where all those are implemented, and that makes for dependance on good tactics above good aim. If you manage to surprise your opponent, you are sure to kill him. This can be done by taking one of the many routes around your enemy while he is engaged in combat with a teammate, or by firing, then sneaking out of sight and hiding in a place he won't expect you. From then on it's an easy kill. You just need to make sure you get there without your opponent knowing. Also, there is aim. Altough deception is the best weapon, sometimes you just need to face each other. There's no way around that. When that happens you need quick reflexes and good knowledge of your gun to quickly dispose of the threat. Before playing even Competitive Casual (the classic no-respawn face-off but with free armor) or Demolition (the classic with awarded weapons), I suggest playing a few matches of Arms Race (Gun Game) to get a feel for the weapons, and then a few matches of Deathmatch (free respawns) to get a better feel for the recoil on your favorite guns. You don't have to master it to get kills, just make sure that the bullets are going forward and not up. Once you've done that, you can get into Casual Competetive and learn the maps by seeing what your buds are doing. The very best way to learn is simply by spectating your team's best player after you've died. I cannot tell you how much he has learned me already. This game has the best gun skins too. Because guns are so realistic the skins have some weight to them, and it gives you a reason not to quit after losing eight matches consecutively. Playing and getting kills with your favorite gun feels awesome. Actually, getting kills in this game is already the most satisfying thing ever, but when it's done with your baby it gets even cooler. The only thing there's not to like about these guns is the fact that snipers exist, but you'll figure that out for yourself soon enough after buying. I figured out how bad snipers were right after booting up CS:S for the first time. I was still loading up when the screen flickered, and I still don't know why, but I got a picture of a man with an AWP jammed down his throat stuck in my head. The barrel was portruding from his belly and blood and intestines lay spread over the sand in Dust_II. I couldn't shake it for the remainder of the loading screen, but I figured out what it meant right after starting my first game. It still haunts me today... Anyway, don't let horror stories like this one frighten you, I'm sure it was just me... BUYBUYBUBYBUYBUYBUYBUYBYUBYUBYUBYUBYUBYUYBUYBUYBUYBUYBUY
game-hours: 741.4

Zastanawiasz si jak przez 350h masz zabija? A n od czego masz onierzu? Karaj noobw w przeciwnym teamie jak rwnie w swoim zajebistym noem ;) Generalnie karaj kadego tym noem kto ci stani na drodze. review: Absolutely love CS:GO! Of all of the Counter-Strike games that have come out since the original, this definitely captures the best aspects of each one of them. There are definitely some little details that make the game-play not as fun; primarily certain physics/logic discrepancies with the environment and the ballistics of the firearms. One of the other downsides to the game is the cost of the in-game purchases for skins. The case drops are fantastic, however the cost of a key for a weapons case being priced at $2.49 seems a bit high. Bottom-line: If you really enjoy team based (and deathmatch) FPS games, you need to get this game!

game-hours: 152.5
review: CS:GO is the most recent entry to the counter strike series, if you're not famillar with this series, its an online tactical first person shooter, developed by the good old people at valve, with hidden path entertainment helping with this entry. it comes with much improved graphics compared to previous entries.. you must be precise and tactical with your movements, the most satisfying thing about this game is mastering the huge learning curve it comes with, and be warned this game is difficult compared to other shooters on the market, but once you become a master at pulling off clean headshots with ease, mastering each each weapon.. trust me you'll be satisfied! Plus the game has workshop support, various skins for each weapons, new versions of classic counter strike maps (dust, office etc.) new game modes are introduced, whilst classic game modes return, and at a fair price, you could do alot worse, Definite Must Buy!

review: My Favorite FPS game ever!! because CSGO is a near-perfect multiplayer shooter. Unlike the previous versions, which were often difficult to get in to, this one offers a variety of modes that will appeal to all skill levels. It has a large community and a well supported workshop, ensuring that this discount-priced game will be around for years to come. In short, you either play as the good or bad guys and must either kill the other team or complete objectives to win the round, which will earn you more money to do the same thing again but faster. It's been around for years and has spawned many imitators.

Every game has down side to it but this game is generally a well put together game with a great community. From past experience the only thing that really does annoy me on this game is the hackers you may come across but they pretty much get a ban. However the game is fun to play and it is very competetive to play. If you have ever played COD then do not compare this game with it... Personally I think CSGO has a lot more skill involved than a couple of killstreaks to do the work for you. Is it worth the purchase? YES! By far yes. I hope this helps anyone who is planning on buying CSGO. I shall make more threads soon. See you on the game! :csgoglobe:

game-hours: 1321.5
review: Counter Strike Global Offensive is the latest installment of the Counter Strike series, and in my opinion the best! The ranking system is one of my favorite features from CS:GO, it gives you the ability to play other players in your skill group. You are given a skill group after playing ten matches. Ranging from Silver 1 (The worst of the worst) all the way to Global Elite (aka pros). Having the ranking system also gives me drive to get better and learn techniques for understanding the game better. A downside is that the default MM Valve servers are only 64 tick, which can lead to your bullets not hitting your target when shooting, but this can be solved by paying for the ESEA 128 tick servers which are far superior. The problem I find most frustrating is the cheaters, now I am not the kind of guy that will call cheats if someone gets a 1-click with an ak-47 but I still find that I run into cheaters on a weekly basis, once again though ESEA has little to no cheaters with there anti-cheat software, so if you are willing to pay a small amount towards ESEA you will find that you will have a much more enjoyable expirience. -Chris Rating - 9/10

game-hours: 2737.6
review: A game where skill is the primary gameplay factor. You level-up yourself, not a character or loadout. You learn the maps, the guns, and the techniques... you memorize recoil timing and bullet-spray patterns and try to get the upper hand whenever possible. Players of other shooters might avoid CS:GO because of the steep learning curve: Don't expect to just drop in and kill, you will find yourself drastically out-skilled. Stick around for a while and you might learn that perfect AK-47 control, and to out-strafe enemies or headshot through smoke using the radar... and all the tricks that I've found fun since I bought Counter-Strike: Source in 2006. Don't forget to check out the Community Scene... all the crazy maps or mods like Surf, ZombieMod, and my favorite- GunGame (now called Arms Race, for some reason... perhaps because COD stole the name). My experience with the Counter-Strike series has been nothing but rewarding and addicting, and I never would have gotten a STEAM account without it. Highly recommended.
game-hours: 2775.0
review: Without a doubt my favourite FPS game that I've ever played. The competitive matchmaking is so much fun, in other Counter-Strike games it was hard to find people who were serious about winning a 5v5 match, very great addition. The new gamemodes are great, really good for some fun casual play when you're bored or dont want to play competitive. Overall one of the most funnest and balanced multiplayed FPS's I've ever played. 10/10.

review: A really big step from CS 1,6 and people are still playing it a lot. The reason probably being that the game never gets old if you learn. This is an anti-game (the more you play at once the more addicted you get). It is an open world first person shooter that doesn't allow you to respawn when you die. The way it's meant to be played - 5v5 you have to buy weapons and kill the enemy team or complete the objective. Since this is an open world game you can go wherever you like and kill whoever you like (yes friendly fire is on). Good game, could be better if the matchmaking would be more balanced.

game-hours: 779.9
review: First, a disclaimer. I am a male senior citizen, a semi-retired gynecologist whose customary literary fare is spy novels and military techno-thrillers. I have never read a romance before, except perhaps for junior high's "A Tale of Two Cities" (or was that a classic?) But after the recent hullabaloo over James' "Fifty Shades," I opted to give the genre a glance. The book's protagonist is college student Anastasia, who has never had sex or even "touched herself." I had to suspend disbelief at the social and sexual naivete of this twenty-one year-old, but I guess this implied vulnerability makes her more attractive as a romantic heroine. Yet it doesn't take her long to rectify this situation, and soon she is having  after  at the behest of her "dominant" partner, Mr. Grey. At my age, my arthritis flared up just reading about Ana's sexual gymnastics. And for some reason, I kept thinking about her contracting genital warts. Soon, however, Ana's endless pyrotechnic climaxes resembled repetitively watching porn: after a while, it leaves me bored and yawning. That said, there was a definite infectiousness to the plot; and taking Viagra to stiffen my resolve, I persevered. James' strong suit is her ability to elicit sympathy in the protagonist. I wanted to find out what happened to Anastasia, and that lent the story a compelling, page-turning quality. James is a polished novelist. Her dialogue is crisp, her prose poised, and her paragraphs well-parsed. The author's considerable skills notwithstanding, would I pick up an erotic romance like this again? Probably not. But that's just me.

review: I have really enjoyed this game - it's one of the best games that I have played. Allthough there are some bugs after major updates, Valve always fix these. Best of all, they listen to the comunity. Map changes have been put in place because we wanted it. There is a massive comunity surrounding this game - because it is an E-Sport, there are international competions held regulary and it offers great YouTube content aswell as amazing Twitch Live Streams. The gameplay itself is epic. I play competetive and it is so tense, the small teams and limited time make it a fast paced, action packed game. If you play with a group of friends or even random people who have microphones, it can become very tactical. There are a few bugs with the matchmaking system, and the low-budget servers can glitch and not register your hits which can be fustrating at times. I would give this game a 9/10.

game-hours: 897.9
review: To all who want this game I give some words of advice. If you have a busy life packed with many things to achieve or accomplish, I would not recommend getting this game. This game, even though one of my all time favorites, will suck all of the time you want to do other things with straight out of your life. HOWEVER, If you are ok with this, welcome to the party! This game is filled with cheap one shot deaths, P90 rushes, aim and wall hacks, smurfs, griefers, trigger and chat spammers, oblivious quitting newbies, impossible life-wasting achievements, and team harassment and cussing through every second of the game. If you want a shiny new knife, don't count on recieving one without spending at least $50. As for guns, you are kitted with stock police-brutality weapons, that can be traded for guns with more style or better patterns. New gun skins range from 4 cents to more than 100 dollars. Top those epic guns off with some one time placement stickers and your changes mean nothing at all (Unless you have a knife or gun worth more than $5). On the bright side, this game is very thrilling and time-worthy on the good days. You need to anticipate the opposing team's actions and work with your team in any match you play. If you set up a competitive queue with a well built team of friends that you can work with and understand their play style, the game becomes an excellent source of entertainment where you can show off your skills as a team. Being a game of Competitive Electronic Sports, you play a game that professional team gamers play, giving you the same qualities and giving you the opportunity to relate to what they do in life. All-in-All, what is better than traveling the world, busting baddies and defusing bombs?

game-hours: 415.1
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is an incredible game. It incorporates many things that made Counter-Strike: Source and the orignal good, as well as delivering a new experience. Now, I'm no professional, but I like this game. Granted, there is a learning curve involved, and you will be killed quite often. But if you get over this, you will enjoy the game. They added a few new weapons, like the incendiary grenade and modified some maps to give a new experience. New game modes, like Arms Race which is basically gungame, were added to stretch out to more audiences. I would definately recommend this game to anyone that appreciates the genre.

review: CS:GO is a very hard and rewarding FPS. It has many things to put into play like the opposing teams money, will they eco or save? If you already don't know what they mean then by playing a few games you'll find out. There is a casual mode but competitive is where CS:GO's 'heart' is at. It's where i've spent most of my time, and I pretty sure that I have became addicted to it, playing 39.3 hours in the last two weeks while tests and school were still on for me. If you came from COD it is a very different game and don't expect to have your hand held or 'piss-fart' around like many do in COD. It is a better experence if your whole team is either friends or have mics. Also you can get skins for your guns AKA camos at some low prices and even make some of the money back when you either upgrade your skin or just get rid of them all together. You wount get good easily, but overtime you will get to a good level. One thing to be weary of opening cases is addicting, you and alot more likely to beable to just buy the skin then get it from a case. I just get mine off the Steam market and it works just fine for me.

game-hours: 31.8
review: Counter Strike has been an epic franchise since my mid teenage years. I have played pre-steam, pre-source, source, and now CS:GO. This game excels as all the others, and brings more the feel of 1.6 that Source lacked. The recoil can be unforgiving so skill is required to control it. It's hard for other games to compare to CS:GO. The quality of hitboxes and the fast intense maps (provided you know the routes and are not wandering around aimlessly) make this an instantly gratifying game. Despite the scandles in the professional scene, this game is excellent and hard to not recommend to any age group.

review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

game-hours: 1475.6
review: 8/10
game-hours: 1151.8
review: CSGO is a near-perfect multiplayer shooter. Unlike the previous versions, which were often difficult to get in to, this one offers a variety of modes that will appeal to all skill levels. It has a large community and a well supported workshop, ensuring that this discount-priced game will be around for years to come. In short, you either play as the good or bad guys and must either kill the other team or complete objectives to win the round, which will earn you more money to do the same thing again but faster. It's been around for years and has spawned many imitators. The game isn't much of a looker as it is based on the same engine as the original Half Life 2 was. However, Valve have polished it as much as they can and the community consists of lots of awesome mappers who have been churning out brilliantly imaginative and beautiful maps almost on a daily basis. Is it worth getting if you already own Counter Strike: Source? Yes. CSS was always Counter Strike shoe-horned into the Source engine. CSGO feels far more like a standalone game. Valve have very carefully listened to what people have wanted and have made a very appealing game. The best feature must be the competitive play, where you play 10 games that you cannot leave (unless you want to tarnish your reputation), after which you'll be ranked and will be paired up with people of the same skill, meaning that the game is challenging but fair no matter what skill level you are. There are all kinds of teams and communities that you can join. Really, if I was stuck on a desert island with one game this would most likely be my top choice. It's bigger than you can hope to conquer and has a huge community around it which will likely be around for years to come, something that can't be said for the Call of Duty franchise which is probably its closest rival. Remember that those games are full price and have another one churned out each year, fragmenting the community. Plus you can customise your weapon skins in CSGO. Surely that's the most important feature?! All they need to add now are hats and you might as well live in CSGO.

review: very gud
game-hours: 733.4
review: Best game :)
game-hours: 387.4
review: The first thing players will notice about CS: GO is how beautiful the game looks. Counter-Strike has always been known as a series that has valued substance over style, but Valve has been more than happy to usher CS: GO into the modern era with breathtaking visuals. Fans will be delighted to see their favorite maps reworked with a fresh and vibrant color pallet. The lighting effects are particularly well crafted as the detailed shadows add another level of depth to many of the games iconic level designs. The new designs are not all flash either, many old maps of the series like Aztec and Dust return with a new design aimed at offering players a more balanced competitive experience. While CS:GO may not support the same over-the-top special effects that other FPS behemoths like Call of Duty and Battlefield are known for, the improvements still prove to be more than noticeable and further entice players to get enthralled in the addicting gameplay. Other than the new look, the gameplay of CS: GO remains relatively unchanged. Sure there are a number of tweaks to the objective multiplayer FPS, but the game still feels, and more importantly plays like a Counter Strike game. That means ungodly aim and perfect map positioning are a must if you want to succeed. As with other CS titles, CS: GO revolves around the players ability to aim, rewarding those who fire in short succinct bursts, while those who spray will find themselves quickly the prey of their more disciplined counter-parts. This aim driven skill intensive combat has long been the staple of the franchise and makes a welcomed return in CS: GO. -10/10

game-hours: 142.1
review: Global offensive is beyond a doubt a throwback to the old school shooters that don't seem to get made anymore. There are no vehicles, and no cover mechanic. You can't bring up iron sights or modify your weapon beyond useless (but colorful) skins. Weapons have a semi predictable spread rather than just going where you aim, etc. These are not neccessarily selling points but they do strongly differentiate CS:GO from other FPS's around today. In fact, GO doesn't really excell at anything when it comes to gameplay except one, singular, but very important thing. Competitive mathcmaking. No other fps has the level of rated competitive play nor the ease of match making. In this respect CS:GO is miles beyond any other game in it's genre. This is the game where your team is what wins, not your personal KDR. Where winning matters because you're not playing complete randoms, you're playing people at your own skill level to see who advances. Compared to modern shooters, this game is ugly, clumsy, lacking content, and overyl simple. It just also happens to be the best competitive FPS in existence.

game-hours: 557.0
review: Despite it's age, CSGO seems to be getting more and more popular! It's easy to see why though, it's a solid FPS with great gun controls ("COD kids" will be put off when they realise they can't spray n pray). It offers lots of modes to ease you in, so you dont have to jump straight in to the "competitive" matches. Team DeathMatch, Gun Game, Demolition and community servers are all available to let you get used to the game. The game also has cases that contains new skins, they dont do anything to your gun other than change it's look, but some of them can be worth a lot of money (Certain knives can be sold for around 200) if you're lucky enough to get 1. Be warned though, a key to a case is 1.59, and unlocking a knife is like winning the lottery! The only bad thing about the game is the amount of hackers/trolls. Lots of matches have been spoiled by someone obviously cheating, or a troll just out to annoy others...

review: The aug at the moment needs to be nerfed, the fire rate is way too fast. It has a similar fire rate of a p90, but does damage like an AK. The aug and the SG, function similar idea, but the AUG is overly stronger than the SG. I would like to disable the BGM in the main menu, but not in the game. The grenades do not bounce off as if they would do in real life, I would liked to have the physics module from CS:S into CS:GO. Also, I want realistics physics that exists in CS:S and not CS:GO. In CS:GO, shooting a barrel is like shooting a wall, it doesn't move when shot. Also, the grenades don't bounce correctly. I extremely dislike the "invisible walls" that block the most obvious spots. Trying to jump onto a ledge but blocked by invisible walls, is just plain "idiotic." To further comment, the updates are specifically designed to affect Comp matches, and less about casual servers. I wish that the updates don't affect too much or if possibly different option for casual servers. Like 20/40 magazine in a M4A1-s, is tactically sound in a comp match, but definitely not made for 32 man server. Other thing, CSGO DOES NOT UPDATE THEIR CLIENT RELEASE INFO MEANING THERE IS NO UPDATE LOGS... so when there is an update, dont expect to find out what was the update about. This frustrates so much, because it takes like 2-3 weeks to figure out the update. this is why csgo is freaking ret4rded when it comes down to "NOTIFYING USERS OF UPDATE LOGS." CS:GO's attempt to "nerf/buff" weapons ruin gameplay drastically... One moment when you are used to it, the next day it is completely different game... That is exactly how StarCraft 2, is dying. CS:GO is currently on the exact path as that game as well. The game will start to die, when you change too many things too quickly. Ruining the p250 (1/9/15), from 5 mags to 3 mags, completely BS. Makes no sense. No one is going to use the p250, just like the CZ75

game-hours: 936.2
review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.
game-hours: 2870.1
review: Revan was only 23 years old. He loved CS:GO so much. He had most of the achievements and items. He prayed to Gaben every night before bed, thanking him for the inventory he's been given. "CS:GO is love," he says, "CS:GO is life." His elder Dragon hears him and calls him a silver scrublord. He knows his elder is just jealous of his son's devotion to Gabe. He calls him a console peasant. He slaps him and sends him to sleep. He's crying now and his face hurts. He lays in bed, and it's really cold. He feels a warmth moving towards him. He looks up. It's Gabe! He's so happy, Gabe whispers into Revan's ear, "Try your chances... Open a case." Gaben grabs Revan with his powerful dev-team hands and puts him on his hands and knees. He's ready. Revan opens his pockets for Gabe. Gabe puts his hands deep into Revan's pockets. It costs so much, but Revan does it for CS:GO. Revan can feel his wallet emptying as his eyes start to water. He accepts the terms and conditions. Revan wants to please Gabe. Gaben lets out a mighty roar as he fills Revan's computer with keys. Revan opens all the cases and gets nothing worth anything at all.

game-hours: 180.1
review: There's birds in this game. I really like birds. Chickens, if you want to be specific. I think the chickens are relatively balanced in the game, their clucking isn't too loud and they flock around the map in a very wonderful way. Some people say that chickens are too OP, as their squawking startles newer players and causes them to cower in complete fear. "Please nerf OP chickens!" they cry, and so chickens were given an unnecessary nerf which greatly ruined my most favourite weapon in the game. I think the biggest flaw in this game, is that there isn't chickens on all the maps. I think every map should have chickens on them, as they provide an immersive and deep strategic element to the game's standard matches, especially in Competitive mode. Another complaint is that there isn't enough variety of birds, I'd like to see different types of birds on each map, like bald eagles on every map that has SEALs on them, or turkeys on Dust maps. Overall, the game is very balanced and refines a long time tradition of celebrating the joyful wonders of avian life, even if it's only a specific type. It's only rarely in games that I see birds play such a significant role in gameplay, and it does it quite well compared to games like Far Cry 3 and Assassin's Creed. You should buy this game if you happen to love birds, as it's a very compelling, rich, and competitive experience for those who do.

game-hours: 582.0
review: At first when the trailer came out for this game in 2012, I was saying to myself that I wouldn't be able to run this game because of the laptop I use.. But 2 years later, I proved myself wrong.... There are a bunch of features in this game which makes this game, among others, the best shooter game that I can play. With CS:GO, you can customise the gun skins to whatever you want, which allows individuality to appear within players. The maps are balanced, which means the bomb areas where you need to plant the bomb are spaced out fairly from each other. I would describe this game as an online game of team-chess, as this game requires 5 players to work together and make decisions on what to do in order to win. However, in my opinion, Valve should add ranked casual so that the newer players who aren't as experienced as the CS veterans are, can play others within the same skill level. Annoyingly, there are many hackers in the silver area (Silver 1 to Silver Elite Master), but they decrease as you go up the ranks. Overall, I would highly recommend this game to anybody and it is well worth the 11.99 (Although I got the CS complete pack for less than 9 during the Fall Sale, but nevertheless, still worth it.)

game-hours: 1211.9
review: CS has always been known as the best competitive tactic fps and this latest chapter isn't different. It isn't famous as other titles which, every year, hit the market, it hasn't the best graphics nor a movie-like story mode, but it's a game only based on pure skill, and that's the only thing that matters. Forget hours playing to unlock scopes and such things, or people killing you cause of better weapons due to their higher rank. In CSGO everyone has the same possibilities (always!), no matter the rank, no matter the amount of hours played, no matter how much money you spent on it. But, in the beginning, you will need time (a lot of time) to fully understand and then improve aim, tactics, economy and teamplay. Give it time to learn, be patient and it will become the only game you'll want to play. If you are a fps enthusiast this is THE must have game!
game-hours: 101.7
review: Stronk game
game-hours: 458.8
review: GGWP
game-hours: 62.6
review: This is by far the BEST co-op teambased first person shooter I've seen in a long time, if not ever. With many team-based tactics per map, I say per map because there's over 20 maps, there's easily a strategy for any gamer who wanders upon this gem of a game. Not only are there map-based strategies, but there's also strategies that are heavily relient on which weapon you use. What's neat about the game is the weapons are accurate. A bullet to the head will result in instant death, no matter how much armor you have, or how 'powerful' persay your weapon is. That being said, bullets to the body still harm you, but depending on if you have armor, the damage may be absorbed. Along with this feature, there's guns. Duh. I say this with a smile on my face because of the main fact that there's lots and lots of guns. Pistols, Heavy, Rifles, Sub-Machine, Grenades, and Gear. All at your fingertips when you begin a round. The game does have a slight learning curve, like that of a hill. Once you get over the first 10 hours, which for me was just playing with bots and against friends, which was mainly just practice and easy for me, learning the maps and such, and the rest of the time is you destroying...udderly destroying your enemies. I myself prefer only two guns: The Nova shotty and the Desert Eagle. I use the Deagle for a long distance gun but I prefer getting up close and personal with the Nova, as I already after 2 hours of getting the StatTrak modification/skin for the Nova from the market. Skins! The game has skins for your weapons. All weapons don't look all the same. I have a Nova reskin that makes it blue. My friend has a pistol that's red. All of them are different and it makes it an overall fun game. StatTrak is a modification that makes everything even cooler. It keeps "Trak" of how many kills you've gathered with that gun specifically and puts that on a counter on the side of the gun, which you can see by holding down F. It's an awesome feature and this game is by far the best co-op shooters I know of. I know after reading reviews that this is redundant but it is the truth! The short version: Pros: Great Graphics Great Sound Awesome Community! Cons: There's a limit to how many competitive matches you can do in a day. Right now I'm restricted to 2 wins a day. 9/10, Thanks Gaben.

review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

game-hours: 204.2
review: That moment when someone headshots you with a jumping Negev across the map. 10/10 best luck/rage simulator 2015. In all seriousness though, this game is great and really fun to play when I'm bored. I have a list of pros and cons, and here they are. Pros: Badass guns like the M249 and AK-47. Actual recoil and accuracy stats for each gun. A variety of types of guns that you need to get used to. Skins. In-game knifes that cost more than real-life knives. Armor. Defusal and hostage rescue kits. Tasers. CHICKENS. Flashbangs. Arms Race game mode to sharpen your skills with guns as you progress to the gold knife. Demolition mode which is pretty much Arms Race but is a bomb situation mission (more on that later). Deathmatch game mode which is Arms Race, but you can just get a certain gun without having to progress. Casual which is a bomb situation mission with the rules of CS 1.6 (no armor, no defuse kits, no chickens D:) Competitive mode which you are ranked, starting from no rank, to Silver I, etc. Ranking system allows you to play with people about at the same rank as you. A  ton of maps. Operations/Campaigns. Crates. Great community. Balanced in-game currency system. A recently nerfed CZ-75 Automatic pistol (basically the worst gun in the game now, previously feared in the pistol round). There's more, but since I suck at thinking, I'm not even going to bother thinking them up. Cons: Ranking system is actually pretty  (you can be one of the best players, get put on the worst teams, and not rank up, while on the contrary, you can be the worst player and get put on the best teams and become a Global Elite before you know it). A lot of the game is luck (consult first sentence of the review). Automatic sniper rifles. Automatic shotguns. Sniper rifles that instantly kill anything above the legs. Machine guns that can shred one apart in half a second. Ragers who call you a hacker every time you kill them (although the community is much better than COD's and TF2's community when it comes to squeakers). Shotgun snipers who somehow headshot and kill you 30 meters away. When you put it all together, its a very fun game and using those cons that involve guns to your advantage can, I admit, be pretty damn fun. But seriously. Extremely fun game. ing buy it now or live your life regretting not doing so.

game-hours: 141.1
review: I recommend this game because its fun, ya know? Get home, play some Counter Strike with friends. And where that can be fun, along side some of the various gamemodes and community modes that are offered, there is always that one thing that lures CS players to GO, Competitive Possibly one of the best and worst features of this game, it when working right, matches you up with people of your skill level and you play it out in a ranked match. The problem with this, and I've experianced this alot lately, is getting into a match with "Those" people. The people who buy secondhand accounts who are truely some god rank player labled as a Silver 2, Or the casual hacker who has the ability to know exactly where you are before you get there, and snap to you like nobodies business. When working properly its great though! but to god either I've magically gotten awful or theres a wave of ^ that going around Graphics: They are pretty good, not the greatest but plays beautifuly at the same time Gameplay: Lacks in some areas, but the overall gamemode variaty and maps make up for it Replayability: Its an addicting game that will most likely hook you right on up Online: Primarly online shooter of course, plays well but does lag spike occasionally Rate: 8.3 Love the game and for what the price is, its worth it, just have to deal with the frustration and Bs from time to time

game-hours: 288.5
review: SWAT vs Terroists, almost like cops vs robbers. Almost. CS:GO is a Tactical First Person Shooter that patches up and fixes up and got to where Call Of Duty failed. In the short description, this is a cheaper and better Call Of Duty. However, there are special things that make it unique. Unlike Payday 2, they actually name the guns the same thing that they're called in real life. Which, for me, is a big plus, and i havent seen many games doing that lately, just making up the gun's own names. They also added nice little micro-transactional skins for the players to buy, to customize their gun. However, some of the guns can go up to 100-200$, while knives go up to 300-1000$. I do want to point out however, i have spent $5.00 on the game itself and im still happy, you don't need to, and aren't pushed to the limit or forced to buy these. And the guns already look good on their own. So, it's just if you have spare change. Also would like to add that if you are a veteran Counter Strike player, you will defintley see that you aren't allowed to choose your skin for your charcter when you join, it automatically sets your skin for you. A small down-grade (for me, not everyone else) because i miss the variety of people on your team. Just adding this in, CS:GO, as you may already know, has tons of unique guns. From the M4A4, to the well-known AK-47, all the way to the un-popular PP-Bizon, and back to the heaviest weapon in the game, the Negev. Along with many, many, more. Anywho, A quick review summarizing some key-points in CS:GO. Final Verdict: 9.2/10.

game-hours: 581.7
review: Must buy if you love FPS games! This game is all about personal progression, since it comes with a high learning curve, it's not about unlocking some stupid grip or scope for your gun. It's about you, that has to learn. The game is updated almost once a week with new features and content, Match Making is great when you are playing with friends. The real game for people that love to play competitively, with a team or just solo. There are also casual game modes available for the people that don't like to play competitively, such as Arms Race, Deathmatch, Hostage and Defusual missions which can be played on casual style, or mostly known as public or community servers. These modes are great to learn the game, and improve your play. Pros.  Match Making.  Skill levels and ranks, play against players of your own skill level.  Competitive scene, with ladders and tournaments.  The CS feeling, transition from older CS games to CS:GO isn't that hard.  Most old maps from CS, are in the game.  No perks and other unnecessary clutter. Cons.  Match Making 64 tick servers.  Game is poorly optimized.  Cheaters now and then, but that's online gaming for you.  RiP Desert Eagle, as we once knew it.
