game-hours: 91.7
review: I'll brief most part of this game so take note some of it for those who are looking to buy this game. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is an FPS game that was created for multiplayer. This game however is a long term support, which means you don't need to worry about either this game won't be "hot" anymore after a year or two as the community is what make this game an LTS unlike Battlefield or COD and so. Speaking of community, people these day keep emptying their wallet to buy keys and start uncrating the case. I'll explain those later. How the game was when you were in for the first time? Well, the menu overlay looks nice just like in Dota 2. It's pretty simple since Valve did some update on it. The menu overlay however is used to be like CSS once in a while. Oh, and don't forget that you'll be greeted like "Welcome to CSGO" and so. Graphics? Well, I'm pretty impressed with it eventhough it was made in Source Engine, realism (maybe a bit) graphics, you can still play it smoothly (around 30 FPS) even with a low tier pc. Currently I'm using Samsung RV411 to play this game, with a resolution of 1024 x 768 and everything on the lowest settings and I'll get around 30 FPS and I'm really satisfied with it. Thumbs up from that to Valve. As a newbie, you might play the tutorial or go singleplayer with the bots. Once that you've done that, you'll probably go ahead and try out multiplayer. I gotta admit that if you play a server with 32 players it won't be fun anymore. Why? "First Come First Killed", crowded, trash talkers, and rage. But then, you'll kept playing it eventhough you won't get a kill from the opposite team. A lot of people keep complain about the MINOR bug in this game, such as you can't show the scoreboard while in-game occasionally, connection issues, hud problems. Still, Valve haven't fix these issues yet. Or they will soon (in Valve time). In CSGO, people get addicted because of skins. Skin is a custom texture applied to the weapon. Skins can also be classified in 8 grade (qualities), from worst to best: Consumer Grade (White) Industrial grade (Light Blue) Mil-Spec (Dark Blue) Restricted (Purple) Classified (Pink) Covert (Red) Rare (Gold) All knives in this game (except the default knife) are rare, it's like uncrating for "unusual hat" in TF2. Don't be surprised why people would pay $400 just for a custom virtual knife. Some weapons have StatTrak which means weapons have led attached to it tracking the amount of confirm killed by the owner. Knives do have StatTrak but that makes it more expensive with it. Two decisions that you made in this game, either just to play it like normal being or end up hooked by those skins. I want my life back. P/S: Sorry for my terrible english or any grammar mistakes. I hope you'll understand what I'm telling.

game-hours: 479.0
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, is the game for people that are competitive. The game makes it competitive by using various teqniques. One of them is having a ranking system which sets you up against people at your level. This makes close matches and also a desire to win. The other thing that makes it is beeing more focused on tactics and team-play than just shooting like in COD. The best thing is that they balance the shooting and the tactics, also weapons, so there aren't any OP weapons, for long atleast. If you don't want to play competitvly, there are more than enough gamemodes for you. But there isn't just positive. after I've played it for a while I can say I'm getting bored of the maps even though there are comming new maps every 3rd month or so. The new maps which are comming are just bad in my opinion. You can also notice that the matchmaking dosen't always work which causes unbalanced matches in competitive. It is still important to remember that I am almost only playing competitive but even if you're not a competitive person, I recommend this game for all FPS lovers. It is even what I would say is a low price for a game. From a scale from 0-100, I would give it a 93.

game-hours: 1274.9
review: This game is amazing! I was a Call of Duty player and after some time I realized how bad it actualy is, so I thought I need something new and I saw this game on sale and I though why not? And it was awesome! First at all the matchmaking works great it's not like when your new your gonna ger dropped in all those high ranked skilled players but with people which have around the same skill as you. Second you need a lot more skill and teamwork for this here is an example: when you're on the terrorist team you need to plant the bomb at site A or B. But on the other hand when you're on the Counter terrorists team you don't know where they are going so you need like 3 people to A and 2 to B if somebody gets shot at A you need your team to help up there. you need quite some skill and a good eye to play this game because you can't aim down your sights and you need to learn the recoil patterns. you also have gamemodes like deathmatch and arms race which need an small improvement on the spawns but after all it's a great way to improve your aim and learning your recoil patterns. You can even earn some money out of it by getting camo's and cases and sell them on the market I made like 10 euro's out of it and bought new weapons for it, how AWESOME is that!? but now we're comming to a verdict I'm giving this game an 10/10 One of the best First person shooters I played :')

game-hours: 74.9
review: I grew up playing Counter Strike 1.6,Condition Zero and Source.I used to play those games every single day with my friends and I remember those days with joy because those were the good old days when we would gather up and lose track of time.The single most important factor of the game's succes is the competitivness.Everybody from the neighbourhood wanted to be the best.And this is why it became one of the most popular and most played franchise. Counter Strike : Global Offensive was considered by many at release,not a worthy successor of the CS franchise.The graphics,the movement,the weapons even the maps were brought up as reasons of the game actually being inferior to the old ones.But as time passed people got used to the game and learned that change is sometimes good. I feel like the game really offers a lot for it's price.It's a modern FPS with key characteristics of the CS games.The game does not forget it's predecessors. The constant patching and updates that are coming from Valve are making the game better and better and I personally think that it has surprassed the quality of the previous games by quite a margin. CS:GO unfortunately has been launched in the era of the MOBA and CoD vs Battlefield.The game has too much of a competition now to ever reach the level of popularity that this franchise had. Nevertheless,the game is solid and if you are a CS fan,you will enjoy it for sure.

game-hours: 827.1
review: 9.2/10 This game is perfect for any person that calls themself a PC gamer... The different skills you have to master to complete this game, are vast. You cannot get good at this game, by playing for a day, a week, or even months! You must be willing to work as a team, while not exposing yourself at the same time; you must practice the aiming technique over time; and you must learn the maps you play. While this is not an easy game, and I cannot even call myself "Good" I've learned to enjoy losing and passing it off as a learning oppertunity, nobody has a perfect profile on this, nobody can always win. Most often when you die, you learn a new sniping location, or shows you a different way to use your favorite gun. Playing competitive can be exactly as the name suggests, but mainly you accept the win or loss and thank the opposing team for the good game, you may get worked up, but after the game you will calm down and start thinking about how to improve your tecnique. A hard game at the best of times, but enjoyable nonetheless.

review: derp skins
game-hours: 339.8
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CSGO), in a nutshell, is a fun FPS with an awesome community. Sure the gameplay is different than other FPS's, but that's because Valve listens to their customers. Counter-Strike has been around for a long time, and it's gameplay has barely changed since it was released. Games like Call of Duty and Battlefield are constantly changing, so what happens is they loose their old fans, and gain new ones. Counter-Strike has always kept their gameplay remotely the same, so they keep their old players, and gain some new ones. For example, in Call of Duty you aim down your sights in order to be more accurate, in Counter-Strike, you crouch. Yes I know aiming down your sights makes more sense, but Valve doesn't care, because they know that their players don't care. I know this was a short review, and I focused more on gameplay than anything, but if you are into FPS's, put this game on your wishlist and buy it when it's on sale. You won't regret it, Valve knows what they're doing.

If you become good and play compet, you will never let it go I promise it will become life. review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. review: A great game with to play with friends, just bring some patience and be ready for one hell of a learning curve (for some, not all). I can't say anything about casual because I don't play it. review: I do not think this is better, nor worse than Counter-Strike: Source. It is just different. And I like different. The Global Offensive guns don't look to shabby. But, with a downfall. It seems they took some out, in place of new ones. And, thought this is my own opinion, seems rather hollow with the pistols. If it just had one more pistol, this would not be needed to talk about. Over all, this game is more than worth it to check out. It's a very great game, and that's why I recomend it. It has a very nostalgic feel to it. Like a 'Blast From the Past' if you would. A VERY weird upside is that, for some reason, I can join servers faster than when playing with bots, and I also have better ping on seldom servers. Another upside is that the game is harder. For any new players of Counter-Strike, this still is a great game, plus, you could still practice with bots or on a practice server. This game makes me smile everytime I hear the short version of Hazardous Environments. It brings you back to the roots of Source. And who cares if the graphics are not up-to-snuff? Graphics are just a pretty little bonous that many people do not realize (for the most part) effect the actual game play. I know that there are more things good with this game than not. And the things that are not are smaller scaled things than the things that are good. And for the record, Valve really did make the game. They just need to give some credit to the people that helped them. For anyone who likes Counter-Strike, or new players, this is a great game. Thank you for your time if you read this. Goodnight and good morning.

game-hours: 196.8
review: :|
game-hours: 308.5
review: This is by far my favorite competitive shooter, even though I've only played 30 hours on it. The game's mechanics are simple and very easy to get used to, even for someone like me who's spent 50% of my time on Battlefield for one year. The graphics are nice and the game runs very smoothly on most computers (I've tested the beta on a 6-7 year old graphics card and it did not dip under 60fps on high settings). The matchmaking usually works fine for both competitive and casual mode, but it can still take a while sometimes. Now, I've said before that the mechanics were simple, but it doesn't mean the game itself is simple, or "easy". Every competitive round is a battle involving your aiming skills, your movement as a team and as an individual, your timing, your intuition and sometimes manipulating the other team psychologically. A match can sometimes be so stressful that it will leave you exhausted and sweating when it's over. Legitimately. An important part of the game is also communication with your teammates. If you learn something about the enemy team, you must use text or voice to tell it to your mates. Playing with a microphone is good, but playing with people you know is even better. The biggest flaw that can be frustrating is the "Come on, this bullet totally got him" feeling, that could possibly be fixed most of the time with 128 tickrate servers instead of 64. To end this awfully written review I'd encourage everyone who hasn't played this to buy it and give it a go. Praise Gaben.

game-hours: 121.5
review: gr8 m8
game-hours: 524.8
review: good game
game-hours: 824.3
review: Type type type type. Review time? I think so. Counter-strike:Global Offensive is a skill/tactics based shooter brought from a company (that I assume) we all know and love, Valve. Valve did a pretty good job on CS:GO, including the recent update of (purely cosmetic and optional) weapon skins and StatTrak counter, helping to fund competitive. You choose a game out of a nice choice of game modes; hostage, defusal, arms race and competitive (plus whatever the community can throw at you), all of which are perfectly executed and stay true to earlier Counter-strikes. What I love in most Valve games, is the adaptation of Source Engine in this game, not a casualized and limited version of the source engine (like L4D2), in which I could use all the commands I was used to, being able to bind and customize the game just how I wanted it without restriction. The graphics in CS:GO are beautiful in the sense of the word, but impractical. CS:S had clear models, each distinguishable from each other easily, where CS:GO's player models are varied per map and slightly blended into each other. While this is easy to adapt to, it is the only flaw I hold against CS:GO. Gameplay is highly tactical and skill based, which you'll quickly discover in competitive gameplay (easily accessed in the play games menu), which is scaled to your level of skill, I may add. Playing with friends outside of your level in competitive is easy and balanced, as the opposition gets a teammate on the same level as your friend. If competitive is not your taste, you still have access to the trademark vanilla server browser, to peruse the community servers (zombie escape? Surf?) courtesy of a button on the main menu. There is also a decent plethora of weapons to use and master, each with favored tactics, areas, and encounters, you'll never be short for choice in a map. The game is very much alive with 27k players in the competitive pool to find servers, and more servers hosted by valve, you will have no problem finding people to play with. I've yet to find an official server that is laggy (thanks to a 'Maximum allowed ping in matchmaking' slider in the options) so all is good there, *cough* chivalry official servers *cough*. As with any source game, community servers have nice plugins that add a flavour and uniqueness to every server, along with custom gamemodes and the such. The game's option menu is fully fledged (which I really wish I could say of many other modern games, I mean, look at Thief II's menu ;_;) and merged with the console functionality is perfectly customizable. An example of this would be that I have the entire f5-f8 group bound to buy certain loadouts in a flash at the start of the round. All in all, if you like competitive gaming fun (or even casual hour-burning sessions), then I gladly recommend this game to you, even if you are new to the Counter-strike series, or a mouse-and-keyboard hardened veteran. get rekt nublets, over and out.
game-hours: 1044.5

game-hours: 803.1
review: Counter Strike............hmmmm ive been playing since about 2010 with css and when i hear about go i was so excited i played it and it was a wonder to behold and now its still amazing hell better than it was before. Well what does it have to offer: Community: The community can be kinda bad mainly when the game goes on sale, thats when the hackers and mental patients buy the game, but mainly its like minded fellows who will actually know how to shoot back and cooperate rather than give a  about hats or skins (on occasions) Skins: The whole skin thing started back in august of 2013 i was there to see it myself and i was way to ing excited to see those things, now the community has taken the side of valve to make the skins themselves as you can see with the workshop and other places where skins might appear. There crates kindof like tf2 except no cosmetics, there skins for guns ranging from these ranks White, light blue, dark blue, purple, red, pink, and a darker yellow (2 items are the yellow rank). these ranks of the skins show their rarity and *cost* so to speak on the skin itself. There is also a quality system for the skins and that ranges from: Factory-New, Minimal-Wear, Field-Tested, Well-Worn, and Battle- Scarred. Gameplay: Well if you have played a Counter Strike then you know what to expect besides the skins, guns, maps, and other goodies. If you are new then are looking at a search and destroy gamemode except thats the main game besides Arms Race(Gun Game), Demolition(A smaller normal cs with gun game qualitys), Deathmatch(who can get the most points by killing people in the given team), and Casual and Competitive(normal cs). There is no create a class so you have to buy your guns at the start of each round, first is the pistol where all u can afford is pistol, armor and grenades. The buy menu is circle where each of the given weapons are shown like rifles, smgs, etc. each weapon cost money and that money comes from killing people or planting the bomb etc. Now to Story. Story: Really...............Really............. you really thought this game had a ing story really my god people im done goodbye *shoots self* Graphics: Its a valve game that uses a enhanced version of the default source engine. If im not mistaken it uses like a Source 2.5 engine i think idk. The graphic quality is probably the best looking valve game mainly because of just how new it is, But other than that it looks very good and is not needing a highly OP PC to be able to run the game im using a decent laptop for gaming and i can run it, my friend's grandma's computer can run it and thats pretty good. Overall Review 9.5/10 This game is off by .5 points because of the community sometimes but other than that you will have a blast playing it i swear to you and hey it goes on sale a ton so if you got a few bucks spend it on go!

You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

game-hours: 2513.0
review: good game
game-hours: 180.1
review: There's birds in this game. I really like birds. Chickens, if you want to be specific. I think the chickens are relatively balanced in the game, their clucking isn't too loud and they flock around the map in a very wonderful way. Some people say that chickens are too OP, as their squawking startles newer players and causes them to cower in complete fear. "Please nerf OP chickens!" they cry, and so chickens were given an unnecessary nerf which greatly ruined my most favourite weapon in the game. I think the biggest flaw in this game, is that there isn't chickens on all the maps. I think every map should have chickens on them, as they provide an immersive and deep strategic element to the game's standard matches, especially in Competitive mode. Another complaint is that there isn't enough variety of birds, I'd like to see different types of birds on each map, like bald eagles on every map that has SEALs on them, or turkeys on Dust maps. Overall, the game is very balanced and refines a long time tradition of celebrating the joyful wonders of avian life, even if it's only a specific type. It's only rarely in games that I see birds play such a significant role in gameplay, and it does it quite well compared to games like Far Cry 3 and Assassin's Creed. You should buy this game if you happen to love birds, as it's a very compelling, rich, and competitive experience for those who do.

review: Counter Strike is known on its big succes. Global Offensive is no diffrent. It brings back what the old Counter Strike was like and gives you a lot more. New multiplayer mods suchs as Arms Race are pretty good so as the new weapons. So much that you can achive with new counter strike. Graphich have been improved but in some point it cant match the new FPS games that have much better graphics. Source engine do its work but not that much to match the new FPS shooters. Also the big lag problem is still there. If you are in a match with a lot of players its going to lag very hard. Overall the new Counter Strike is very good and feels awesome. It brings back what the old CS had and gives you some new features. New guns, mods maps and a lot more can drag you in hours of playing. 9/10

game-hours: 257.6
review: I thoroughly enjoy CS:GO. mostly the competitive aspect as I don't enjoy the casual gamemodes. Now, although competitive is full of hackers/trolls/smurfs it is an incredibly fun and engaging way to play. It teaches you how to play and there are many helpful guides online. The negatives, if you have a team who don't communicate it is a large issue as you cannot give information about the enemy and disucss tactics. Also, smurfers and hackers ruin matches but are vital in the learning curve of CS:GO as they teach you how to make better decisions and keep your cool. As myself, coming from mostly LoL I didn't struggle to pickup the game and found it as a great way to relax in casual gamemodes or play competitively. One large thing I didn't mention earlier is getting banned automatically. For example, you can become banned from kicking too many teammates, which I think is ridiculous, but is implemented. So a few tips, don't kick people unless you really have to and don't afk/leave. This will save you from some bans. It requires you to be proactive with your learning of the game to find tutorials and learn from more experienced players to do things such as strafe shooting and headshotting. If you can master these techniques you can do greatly. The ranking system is slightly confusing but requires you to win many rounds and games successfuly to rank up. It can become annoying but you will eventually rank up. TL;DR Great competitive scene, easy to learn but hard to master. Buy this game if you're looking for an FPS game that is unique and enjoyable to play with friends. 9/10 10/10 (If hackers and smurfers were lowered, but we all know that isn't possible)

review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is probably my favorite game right now becuase of the possibilities in-game. You have all the weapons in the game to start of with, but there is a lot of skins to make them look better. There is a huge amount of skins you can collect from cases, marketing and betting. You can also get nice drops from missions. The game is almost all about statrategy and chemistry between players. There is also different roles. The most played gamemode is probably Competetive. After 10 matches won, you will receive a rank that will organize who you are gonna play with. The ranking system is based on the ELO system. There is also Deathmatch, Arms Race and Casual. The CS:GO community is huge and I could easily give this game a 10/10 becuase of that.

game-hours: 581.7
review: Must buy if you love FPS games! This game is all about personal progression, since it comes with a high learning curve, it's not about unlocking some stupid grip or scope for your gun. It's about you, that has to learn. The game is updated almost once a week with new features and content, Match Making is great when you are playing with friends. The real game for people that love to play competitively, with a team or just solo. There are also casual game modes available for the people that don't like to play competitively, such as Arms Race, Deathmatch, Hostage and Defusual missions which can be played on casual style, or mostly known as public or community servers. These modes are great to learn the game, and improve your play. Pros.  Match Making.  Skill levels and ranks, play against players of your own skill level.  Competitive scene, with ladders and tournaments.  The CS feeling, transition from older CS games to CS:GO isn't that hard.  Most old maps from CS, are in the game.  No perks and other unnecessary clutter. Cons.  Match Making 64 tick servers.  Game is poorly optimized.  Cheaters now and then, but that's online gaming for you.  RiP Desert Eagle, as we once knew it.

If you want to challenge yourself with a game that you can take a bit more seriously than your average competitive FPS game, Buy. This. Game. This game is brilliant in my eyes. There aren't any other competitive FPS's out there that can rival this one when it comes to a perfect balance of skill and fun all in one. game-hours: 199.8
review: Counter-Strike: Gloabal Offensive is a tough and challenging game, it's fun and tactical but has a pretty steep learning curve. If you like shooters and you like a challenge then this game is definitly worth the money. Offers diversity in playstyles (tdm, demolition, competitive, etc) and has really good game mechanics. I would like to add that the game is extremely costumizable to your own personal liking! One big negative point is how the system handles the performances of individual players. If you are unlucky and get placed in really bad teams (people that are afk, team killers, etc) you won't rank up even though you have a kill death ratio of 4 and do everything right, the sytem will keep you in the lower ranks just because you lost, simple as that. If you manage to win a few rounds in a row you do get promoted very fast but some people can get extremely unlucky and be stuck in a rank that hurts them more then it helps them for a pretty damn long time. One last thing is cheaters, there are a lot of cheaters on CS:GO and they can buy the game again for a small price if they get banned. This needs to be dealt with because no one likes cheaters and everyone hates meeting them so do keep this in mind. The last two points sound pretty negative but the good things outweigh the bad and all together that makes this game a clear winner amongst tactical shooters!

review: This game is great, it is so pleasing to note that valve has given such a contribution to the face of modern Fps games. It has great core gameplay that is quick and flows into itself swiftly and easily. At least if a CT isn't camping a point with an awp, but that's besides the point. I haven't played much, but what I have seen tells me that this game is engaging, fast paced and (without trying to make it sound like the most important thing ever) has some of the best graphics I have seen valve produce. Also, Are we rushin' in? Or are we going all sneaky beaky like? Only negative I can really see is the scalding you get from people better than you if you go in competitive too early. This can be a drag for me, as I am merely a begginer, but the one liners the teams give and they gameplay earns this game, to me, a 7/10. review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

Counter-strike is a game where you are forced to think about every move you make because it could cost alot and leave you having to save a round. Last but not least is this game is not at all like 1.6 because noone and i mean noone from the noobs side of the game will ever knife fight and if they do it will be a 2v1 or worse. -_-. In conclusion Counter-Strike Global Offensive is my favorite game and i highly recommend it if you are looking for a tactical shooter. 10/10

game-hours: 1075.7
review: Okay for all of those people out there who hate this game because of hackers, I feel you. in the last 12 hours I've had 3 of them in my games. I feel like more people need to know how to spot a hacker, since usually when you call hacks someone is like "maybe he's just really good". First, if they have less than 5 hours and they're REALLY good, there's a possibility VAC just hasn't banned them yet. Next if they are set to "private" they could just not want you to see their profile. Also if the player has no skins at all and they're insta headshotting all game, there's another big red flag. Hackers destroy this otherwise awesome game. I got a game where a players last vac ban was 11 days ago. 11 days! And he's back on CS:GO? Why are these hackers let back on? There aren't perma bans for these guys? Honestly anything less than and IP ban isnt' acceptable. I know of other software companies who get in contact with your ISP if you are causing them grief. Why does valve allow these cheaters? Well I can't blame Valve for the game, the game is amazing. But please fix the VAC. Or at least tell me how to minimize hackers while I play this. Thank you very much, Strogunoff

game-hours: 652.6
review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is the latest installment in the Counter-Strike series. Nothing much has changed in this installment other than updated graphics. Veterans to the series are going to love Counter-Strike: Global Offensive but newcomers... sadly I cannot guarantee that you will like this game. Even if you know you like the game, the very difficult learning curve might get to you before you even have a chance to completely enjoy the game. But it's worth giving the game a shot. To some it's too old school and it lacks features the new flashy modern First Person Shooters have; ADS (Aim Down Sights), Sprint etc. But in my opinion this one of the greatest FPS' out on the market. What most FPS' lack is a sense of competitve nature. Sure you can make bets and "CMON BRO 1v1 ME BRO I'LL SMASH YOU" people but in my opinion it's not enough. If you love competitve gaming particually in FPS' then there's another point to Counter-Strike. There are so many things that make Counter-Strike: Global Offensive a worthy game in your Steam Game Library for me to list! So do me a favor, do the Counter-Strike community a favor and pick up this game! For around $15.00 AU (Don't know how much in other currencies, I'm sure you can do the math! >.<) you're getting a good deal! Operations which are like free DLC updates but have limited time on playing the maps that are released in the operation, Skins which are probably the most infectious disease in a game second to the infamous Team Fortress 2 hats! and overall just fun! u2late approves! :D Notes: -Sorry if there are grammar and spelling mistakes! I typed this up without checking for errors (Sorry grammar nazis! :P) -Like this up if you found it useful so others can see! -HAVE FUN!

game-hours: 735.8
review: This is a great game that is difficult to play because it has alot of things to master and pick up like grenade spots, angles, where to aim while moving, map sense. It also helps on improving reflexes and muscle memory, but the most important thing is experience, for example a player who has played cs 1.6 or source will have a better time playing this game, whilst a player who has never played a shooter before will have a really harsh time and will need about 300 hours to start picking out more than 2 kills per round. A person who has played a shooter of any kind will have an edge over the regular casual player. On the other hand the game lets you play competitive from the moment you start, but do keep in mind if you don't have any experience in game it is not recommended to play this mode instantaneously, as it will ruin others' experience and you will most likely be insulted (never take those insults to heart). Overall a begginer will honestly get "pwned" when he starts because of the harsh enviroment of learning. Don't be discouraged to buy this game if you haven't played anything like this, it will be a great experience. 10/10 (not a fanboy score) Thanks for readin' Peace ~.~
game-hours: 28.8
review: Combine the peppers, garlic, onions, salt and oil in a non-reactive saucepan over high heat. Saute for 3 minutes. Add the water and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, for about 20 minutes, or until peppers are very soft and almost all of the liquid has evaporated. (Note: this should be done in a very well-ventilated area!) Remove from the heat and allow to steep until mixture comes to room temperature. In a food processor, puree the mixture for 15 seconds, or until smooth. With the food processor running, add the vinegar through the feed tube in a steady stream. Taste and season with more salt, if necessary. (This will depend on the heat level of the peppers you use as well as the brand of vinegar used.) Strain the mixture through a fine mesh sieve and then transfer to a sterilized pint jar or bottle and secure with an airtight lid. Refrigerate. Let age at least 2 weeks before using. Can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 6 months. Read more at:

game-hours: 412.4
review: CS:GO is a...different game then cod. if you expect there to be sights on anything other then something with a scope on it and you absolutely hate that, and/or you have a VERY bad internet/computer, don't play it. Go get cod. Otherwise, you open up to a slightly different fps where you work with your teams in 5 different modes: Deathmatch, Arms race, Demolition, Casual, and Competitive. These different modes give a wide diversity to how you can play the game. Knowing the map your in and how you should deal with the positions of the enemy players is a big part of the game. And also, one of the greater aspects of the game, YOU CAN MAKE MONEY. LITTERALLY. By playing this game, after matches you have a chance to get either a skin or a crate, like the huntsmans crate or, if your lucky, a p250 franklin. These can be sold in the market for money on steam that you can use to buy games or buy other skins on the market. Or, you can go into a group or discussions and find someone who might want to trade with you. Quite honestly, if you play it enough and enjoy it, you can earn (quite litterally) your money back easily! I highly reccomend it to players who want to have a slightly different style of play. EDIT: The community is utter . Expect people, ESPECIALLY in the silver league, to be absolute S.

game-hours: 263.7
review: This is actualy a Great game. It reminds me a lot of Cod one with a lot more Tactics. The Quality of the game is Pritty low, aka its graphics are pritty dated and souch. but I my self have never been fussed about that, because even on the Worlds worst computer you will still get great gameplay. The game modes in this game are strong. There are The two Main gamemodes, Casual (wich is exactly what the title portays, just casual Best of 15 games round, with Basic rules and no team Killing) And what The Proper people play when they feel like it or have time, Competitive. competitive is a surios Gamemode. before entering, the game its self gives you a warning saying that comp matches May Last up to an Hour and a Half, and Leaving mid game or otherwize, once joined will resalt in a gradualy Increasing Penalty. That imidiatly makes the game mode very intimidating. Then theres the People. If you Get a good team that Sayes "bad luck, bud" if you mess up, your fine. but thats rare. if you dont do what the general rabble wants you to do, you will get Yelled at, Trolled, abused & kicked in that order. People get realy surios. The game mode is not for New players, so make sure you play a lot of casual first. The People who play the game are not like any other. the comunity is thick, and nice to be a part of. a wize man once said to me; "you'l meet some pritty Out there People." and he was right :D your in for a treat. People range from desgusting little Squeekers carrying on about how were so bad that wele still be here when its there bed time at 7pm, to PROPER mlg's that get 54 kills and 3 deaths in 15 rounds. you will meet enimys and Mates. and you will love it. Something That Atracts The Most People to this game is the Skins & trading of said skins. Skins, the External Colouring and designs of the ingame firearms, are Extremely extensive. Skins range from the Usual skins that you can get from Drops after games (if your lucky) that People sell for around $0.04-$0.10, all the way up to Knife skins that are so rare, if you tryed to buy one it would set you back up to $400 at a time. This is real money, But its realy hard not to get mixed up with Trading and ALL of your money will slowly 'leak' out of your acount as you try harder and harder to get the good skins. one way to get rare skins is opening Weapons cases. These cases are what people waste the most money on. the cases themselfs are usualy only between $0.05-$0.20, but the case keys themselves are what costs the money, $2.50 . There is a chance to make your money back, and make a Huge Profit, but its so rare, that People spend hundreds of dollers on keys and cases and they only get $0.04 skins each time. ONLY OPEN CASES FOR FUN, NOT TO MAKE PROFIT BECAUSE THE CHANCES ARE YOU WILL NOT GET ANY! Sticker capsules are Better. they are cheaper. wich brings me to stickers. Stickers, are just ingame stickers. large Decoritive stickers that you put on teh side of your guns for Fation and Fun, or increase the Value of the weapon. stickers range from teh cheapest $0.30 ones, to rare Holo's, foils and golds wich change the apearance of teh stickers, wich can set you back $15 Up for the good ones. All of this stuff is good for trading. teh more expencive the item is, obdviosly the more you will get out of the trade. But There are Many problems with trading: -Low Ballers -Scammers -Profit Pugs etc. Low Ballers tend to only give you half of what your offering in Item Value. they dont want to give you any profit, and they Basicaly are only there to piss people off or get an awsome deal off some spud who deosnt realize there low balls. Scammers are a big Problem. i recently Lost an AK-47 blue laminate with about $3 worth of stickers on it to a Scammer. i was quite much a nub at trading then, and thats how they get you. some may offer real money for the Items. This CANNOT BE DONE THROUGH STEAM. REMEMBER THAT <--- because the guy who scammed me, copyed a recept from a $5 steam wallet perchase, with service links and all to make it look legit. he changed some words around, and made it look Emaculatly real. so ofcource i got a bit exited. so exited, i didnt read the Email properly. in the YELLOW WRITING it said: This person is offering: nothing - WARNING! YOU WILL NOT GET ANYTHING OUT OF THIS DEAL. IF THE OTHER TRADER HAS OFFERED YOU MONEY, IT MAY BE A POTENTIAL SCAM!" and then over to teh right in The custom msg box he had his deal. as soon as i accepted it the comunication between us stopped. i spammed him and abused him, but it was to late. BE VERY CAREFULL WHEN TRADING. Otherwize, trading can be realy fun. you can get tons of crapy skins and to the right buyer, you can trade them all for one you realy like. then you can use it ingame, and people can see how pro you are with your OG skin :D. so over all, i would recomend this game. The game play is Great fun, and extremely adictive. The Skin trading is surios and fun as well. The Comunity whome you will be playing with is great as well. its a simple, yet complex. Surios, yet Casual and fun. its a perfect mix, and at the momant its one of the best games iv played ever. By all means, Get this game.

review: Couter-strike global offensive is a very smart game. It's a game that's too smart to just say "Hey, here's a gun, go send some guys to hell..." It's a game that tells you that but also tells you "And those guys are all smarter, stronger, better and everything you can imagine than you". It's a game that keeps you on your toes every minute your playing it. Counter-strike is a series of games that have a HUGE community. Who never spent days, months, years playing CS 1.6? It has some very talented players playing it and if you're not prepared for it, your gonna get stomped by them. You're probably going to spend a lot of hours in the spectator mode, but you know what? That's just fine. It's going to be hard, it's going to be frustrating, but that's the fun! Learning from your mistakes is fun and after a lot of practice, your going to love this game. After all that time, your going to realise why this is such a popular game.

review: It doesn't matter how good you are any more, you will be judged solely on the market value of your inventory. You should have one of your several Karambit knives equipped at all times and inspect it in game whenever possible to ensure that anybody who is spectating you is aware that you are aware you're being watched and you are absolutely showing off that extremely pricey knife you own. Your stats are irrelevant now, most people aren't even aware that the 'Tab' key actually has a function in game. It doesn't matter if you don't know what 'eco' means. Fuck team work. You have a 'BOOM' AWP in your inventory, as long as you have $4750 cash in game you're buying an AWP. You will mock anyone who decided to give their Nova the 'Walnut' skin. Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Disregard the fact that you will end up spending three times as much as you otherwise would've by buying this directly from the market, it's only your parents' money after all. Besides, your birthday is next month and Christmas/Easter/[insert public holiday here] is just around the corner so you won't have to wait too long before you can blow more of their money on digital goods. You will also plaster ever single skin you own with multiple unseemly stickers with the intention of creating a unique skin for your weapon. Your 'Easy Peasy' and 'Ninjas in Pyjamas' stickers totally don't look ridiculous whatsoever. You will also name tag all of your weapons in order to add that final personal touch to the weapon you invested so much time and money in. You don't own an AK or an M4 any more, you only own weapons with names like 'xXx OG Snoop Dogg' and 'dubstep warrior'. You now have all the knowledge required to start playing CS:GO. Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

game-hours: 310.5
review: The first thing players will notice about CS: GO is how beautiful the game looks. Counter-Strike has always been known as a series that has valued substance over style, but Valve has been more than happy to usher CS: GO into the modern era with breathtaking visuals. Fans will be delighted to see their favorite maps reworked with a fresh and vibrant color pallet. The lighting effects are particularly well crafted as the detailed shadows add another level of depth to many of the games iconic level designs. The new designs are not all flash either, many old maps of the series like Aztec and Dust return with a new design aimed at offering players a more balanced competitive experience. While CS:GO may not support the same over-the-top special effects that other FPS behemoths like Call of Duty and Battlefield are known for, the improvements still prove to be more than noticeable and further entice players to get enthralled in the addicting gameplay. Other than the new look, the gameplay of CS: GO remains relatively unchanged. Sure there are a number of tweaks to the objective multiplayer FPS, but the game still feels, and more importantly plays like a Counter Strike game. That means ungodly aim and perfect map positioning are a must if you want to succeed. As with other CS titles, CS: GO revolves around the players ability to aim, rewarding those who fire in short succinct bursts, while those who spray will find themselves quickly the prey of their more disciplined counter-parts. This aim driven skill intensive combat has long been the staple of the franchise and makes a welcomed return in CS: GO. As with the core gameplay mechanics, the two premier game modes Hostage and Defuse remain fundamentally the same. For those of you unfamiliar with Counter Strike both game modes work under the same premise, with two teams the Terrorists and Counter-Terrorists (CTs) pitted against each other. The game is split into rounds (usually best of 30), where players attempt to achieve the assigned objectives; but the real kicker is, that each mode hosts perma-death meaning when you die you are dead for the duration of the round. Unlike other popular shooters that use a class system, CS lets players define their own class buying equipment, armor, and tools at the start of each round, if you survive the round your items will be transferred into the next round, but if you die you will have to buy everything all over again (if you can afford it). The real difference between the two modes lies in their objectives, in defuse the terrorists attempt to plant a bomb at one of two bomb sites, while the CTs attempt to defend the positions. Inversely in Hostage the CTs are charged with rescuing a group of hostages while the Terrorists attempt to keep them contained. The only real notable change to Hostage and Defuse is the addition of Competitive and Casual versions of each mode. Competitive is the standard version of each game mode from pervious installments of the series. Players will have to buy their armor, friendly fire and player clipping is turned on, and team size is restricted to 6v6. Perhaps the most interesting facet of Competitive mode is the new ranked matchmaking system, that looks to pit players against their peers based (win/loss ratio). This is a welcomed addition as it ensures that good players will find the quality competition that they are looking for, while also allowing new players a chance to play against opponents more relative to their skill level. On the other hand, Casual mode offers a high intensity carefree experience. Friendly fire is turned off, players spawn in with full armor, and kills produce 50 percent less cash. The 50 percent reduction in money gains really sets this game mode apart from Competitive. It helps keep the mode balanced as players will find themselves with additional funds from not having to purchase armor at the start of each round, but it also insures that better players do not receive too much of an advantage over the opposition. One of the most common complaints with previous Counter-Strike games was that the games high skill curve creates a barrier to entry for many new players new to the franchise. With deaths being as quick and merciless as they are, and a large portion of the CS community having been playing the tactical shooter for the better part of a decade, learning the skill comprehensive combat can be quite an obstacle. Luckily Valve thought of this and in turn created, the Arms Course a small simple tutorial, but something the series desperately needed. Running through the quick gauntlet will teach you all the basics, while it will hardly give you the skills you need to face the hardened veterans that await, it will at least let you understand the basics. Additionally players will also be able to refine their skills in custom games against bots or even partake in two new Arsenal modes, which spawned from the popular Gun Game Modes in Counter Strike: Source and 1.6. Arms Race is the traditional version of gun game pitting two teams of players against each other in what appears to be a traditional TDM setting. When players are able to kill an enemy on the opposing team they will move on to the game, the first player to move through the entire weapon rotation, ending with the ever impressive knife kill is victorious. Demolition on the other hand plays much more similar the classic Defuse game mode. Just as it is in the classical CS: GO game mode when a player dies in Demolition they're dead for the entirety of the round, however unlike the original game modes there is not shop, instead as players get kills their arsenal changes. Typically the guns are downgraded as players get more kills actually making it easier for players who are doing worse to kill their opponents in the next subsequent round. These new modes serve as a great entry for new players allowing them to try a variety of the games weapons, while working on their aim. Besides the two new game modes, Valve also introduces eight new weapons into the game. However, the new weapons feel more like redesigns as each new gun basically serves to replace an old gun. For instance the Schmidt Scout sniper from Counter-Strike Source is gone, but it has been replaced with the SSG 08, a sniper that does relatively the same damage and even has a similar look and feel. Some of you might be upset that Valve isn't offering an impressive new cache of weapons, but in truth their old trusted selection of weapons and tools serves them quite well. CS has been using similar weaponry for almost as long as I have been gaming and that has helped the series to continue to produce one of the most balanced completive weapon sets ever seen in a FPS. +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Gives CS a much-needed facelift Cheap cheap +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ ---------------------------------------------------------- Nothing revolutionary here ---------------------------------------------------------- Thanks for reading! :3

review: Counter Strike............hmmmm ive been playing since about 2010 with css and when i hear about go i was so excited i played it and it was a wonder to behold and now its still amazing hell better than it was before. Well what does it have to offer: Community: The community can be kinda bad mainly when the game goes on sale, thats when the hackers and mental patients buy the game, but mainly its like minded fellows who will actually know how to shoot back and cooperate rather than give a  about hats or skins (on occasions) Skins: The whole skin thing started back in august of 2013 i was there to see it myself and i was way to ing excited to see those things, now the community has taken the side of valve to make the skins themselves as you can see with the workshop and other places where skins might appear. There crates kindof like tf2 except no cosmetics, there skins for guns ranging from these ranks White, light blue, dark blue, purple, red, pink, and a darker yellow (2 items are the yellow rank). these ranks of the skins show their rarity and *cost* so to speak on the skin itself. There is also a quality system for the skins and that ranges from: Factory-New, Minimal-Wear, Field-Tested, Well-Worn, and Battle- Scarred. Gameplay: Well if you have played a Counter Strike then you know what to expect besides the skins, guns, maps, and other goodies. If you are new then are looking at a search and destroy gamemode except thats the main game besides Arms Race(Gun Game), Demolition(A smaller normal cs with gun game qualitys), Deathmatch(who can get the most points by killing people in the given team), and Casual and Competitive(normal cs). There is no create a class so you have to buy your guns at the start of each round, first is the pistol where all u can afford is pistol, armor and grenades. The buy menu is circle where each of the given weapons are shown like rifles, smgs, etc. each weapon cost money and that money comes from killing people or planting the bomb etc. Now to Story. Story: Really...............Really............. you really thought this game had a ing story really my god people im done goodbye *shoots self* Graphics: Its a valve game that uses a enhanced version of the default source engine. If im not mistaken it uses like a Source 2.5 engine i think idk. The graphic quality is probably the best looking valve game mainly because of just how new it is, But other than that it looks very good and is not needing a highly OP PC to be able to run the game im using a decent laptop for gaming and i can run it, my friend's grandma's computer can run it and thats pretty good. Overall Review 9.5/10 This game is off by .5 points because of the community sometimes but other than that you will have a blast playing it i swear to you and hey it goes on sale a ton so if you got a few bucks spend it on go!

review: When I watch the trailer, it was pretty fun as if I was watching a movie about terrorist assault. However, the game itself is quite different from the trailer. Not much can I say, in the trailer, I can see there's lots of teamwork shown by Counter-Terrorist (CT). Also, when the Terrorist guy picked up the machine gun which I assumed a Negev, he shot one CT guy to death easily like there is no recoil. And whatever he shoot (like the wooden crates or the radioactive barrel) toppled down. But in the game itself, those are completely different. The maps are just artificial but simple. The Negev has high recoil, but still preferred for the ability to spray the whole area down. Also, the community here is disappointing. Some of them may co-operate and has high skills and teamwork. But the others, just blaming and taunting or even worst, they teamkilling or feeding the enemies. ******************** But who the hell cares? This game has everything! Bombs, weapons, explosive stuffs, grenades, and MORE maps! If you like realistic FPS games, you better grab one. I recommend playing this because the community has good communicating skills. They won't keep silent and go solo (or yolo) but will stick and co-operate. This is why I love this game! P/S: Sometimes you get weapon drops after each game which you can sell at the market for money. Or you can be creative and design your own weapon skin using the workshop and make money (I guess). 10/10 would play.

Same goes for people who give their FAMAS the 'Doomkitty' skin. You will only equip 'StatTrak' weapons and the first thing you do when you acquire one is go on an idle server and get several hundred kills on AFK players in order to pad the stats so you don't look like a total n00b. Whenever a new case is released you will buy as many cases and keys as it takes in order to acquire 'an Exceedingly Rare Special Item!' Go forth and procure many skins of great value.

review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is probably my favorite game right now becuase of the possibilities in-game. You have all the weapons in the game to start of with, but there is a lot of skins to make them look better. There is a huge amount of skins you can collect from cases, marketing and betting. You can also get nice drops from missions. The game is almost all about statrategy and chemistry between players. There is also different roles. The most played gamemode is probably Competetive. After 10 matches won, you will receive a rank that will organize who you are gonna play with. The ranking system is based on the ELO system. There is also Deathmatch, Arms Race and Casual. The CS:GO community is huge and I could easily give this game a 10/10 becuase of that.

game-hours: 461.3
review: This game... where do I even start. I could mention all of the great guns Counter-Strike:Global Offensive starts you out with, but gives you a "bots" mode that serves as a tutorial, and a gamemode all the same. It's a great and fun way to learn all of your guns while still being treated as the newer player you are, if you are one. This game has elements from both the Source engine and the 1.6 engine, corresponding to the original Counter-Strike, running 1.6, and Counter-Strike:Source, running, well source. In this manner it appeases to fans of all ages, both newbies and veteran Counter-Strike players. It also has amazing looking new "guns," or gun skins. For some going to only 4 cents on the market, people can acquire some easy skins that can change up your playstyle, or very expensive (100-400 dollar) gun camos, for collectors who like to have only the best. It throws you off a bit if you are used to First-Person Shooters like Call of Duty or Battlefield in the fact that you cannot sprint, and aim-down your sights on all of your weapons. Even so, it teaches you the skill of learning your accuracy and how to shoot effectively to take down your opponents. So let me recap: (PROS) Great sort of tutorial, appeases to new fans and veterans, cheap but nice looking gun camos, teaches you skill. (CONS) Best gun camos are REALLY expensive, throws you into matches with players LEAGUES better than you occasionally, and is a tad bit difficult to master. I am, as you can see by my time played, nothing more than a decent player, for the n00b I am. So don't take my word for it. Go talk to someone with hundreds of hours, and see what they have to say. This is not but a small recap of the pros and cons of CS:GO, and why I like it. 9.2/10

game-hours: 618.6
review: Well i always was i CS1.6 player. Later i tried the CS:S, i didn't like it at all. Later the CS:GO beta came out, and i tried it, if it's better than CS:S, but it wasn't. But now, it is better than both previous games. Why? Because CS:GO is mixing the best parts of both games. Pros: - Matchmaking system, with Competition mode, and ranking - New gamemodes by default, like Deathmatch, Armsrace, Demolition - De_nuke has some great changes (secret is more close to T spawn) - You get money for playing CS:GO (Since i started playing CS:GO, i'm sure i got 30+  without opening any cases.) - Great Operation maps - Pretty fun with friends - Stattrak skins - Blueshell effect (if your team looses more rounds in a row, you get more money at the next round start, so you can afford to full buy every round.) - Community events (Dreamhack winter, EMS Katowice...) - Very cheap. If you are lucky, you can buy it for 2. Cons: -Too many hackers (i know, if you play against hackers, that match will not count as a defeat) - Failing Matchmaking system, sometimes i get in a match, my team is nova gold 3-4, the enemy is Golden AK. Or the enemy team is around nova gold 3, and i get unranked/silver teammates. - Too many smurfing players. High skilled players (Global Elite) make a second account, just to pwn the silver-gold players. (I just got deranked, because of that a few minutes ago.) - Operation maps don't last forever. - Too many players don't speak english at all. (Last night i lost 3 matches in a row, just because my team spoke french, spanish, russian, polish, german, but not english.) - Too many ragekids, who are the last in your team, but wants to kick you out of the match, or just shoot you in the head for no reason at all. - Hitbox is still buggy. I love to see that, i shot somebody in the head, his blood squirts to the wall behind him, then he kills me. Then I check the console, and it says i dealt no damage to him. Valve pls... - Skins. Some of them are overpriced as **** - Terrible spray for AK - Horrible spawn system in Deathmatch. (Just like in any CoD game or worse) - No storyline at all.

game-hours: 248.6
review: For all the long-time players and fans of Counter-Strike, the newest installment of Global Offensive will surely put your joy meter soaring up to the sky. Generally speaking, Global Offensive (CSGO) manages to implement tournament-like gameplay than previous Counter-Strike series. In it, Valve combining live matches features, so we can watch tournament live streaming; the other features is major updates from previous gamemodes, where now we have multiple sets of tourney-like rules in a map, which inline with the - on my opinion - way Valve want this game to be : as an e-sports game. "Before we go further, I would like to talk about Valve wants to bring CSGO as "e-sports qualified game", which in my opinion, are becoming like Dota 2 which massively supported by Steam to generate revenue via tournaments that they really put a big budget on it. As example is how Dota 2 has "The International", annual prime Dota 2 e-sports competition. By that, if you are CS fans in particular or FPS lover in general that wishes to play a game that might gets you onto a tournament, this is it. Intergrated match streaming, community geared towards tournament, mode rules to cater for competitive play and sportsmanship, player stats to track your progress, all in all to support the Valve and Steam goal to - once again, my opinion - put forth CSGO as sweet candy to collect professional team and put them into tournament (to get them more money, of course :) But hey, thats on positive word :) Besides, those who join the tourney does gets their gaming career even more further than before). Alright, now you know how ambitious Steam and Valve is to make CSGO an e-sports game and setting their own e-sports event, but paragraph below will talk about the CORE of why CSGO differs (or maybe not) from previous installment. So, take the tourney world and put it somewhere first, I'm not gonna review that further." On to the top of the ocean, CSGO does have increment over its previous series, especially the engine they uses. I'm not really expert at it, but it does makes the game more or no less better than CS:Source. Of course, that means new maps, overhauled old famous maps for newer engine, some new weapons and equipments (but also removing certain old weapons that's been present on previous CS series), kinda-new gameplay mechanics, new features like supported by Steam Market which you can buy and sell weapon skins, new "training" mode to play all available game modes in CSGO, achievements expanded, inventory system tied with the Steam Market to uses and keep your weapon skins, and more. Now, to talk deeper about the relations of Steam Market, in CSGO we can get drop loots at the end of the round, which could be a weapon or a case (you need key to unlock it) and you could sell it via Steam inventory to gain Steam Wallet money. Then newer this and newer that, it's just that CSGO is newer and improved. Sounds like a good next-gen CS game, eh? Because it is. Now, because they uses newer engine than CSS, it obviously has certain differences from CSS gameplay. One example is how the recoil works and player movement. It's now different, unlike CSS. Does it bad? Well, for me, I don't find anything bad about it, but on normal game I couldn't find any difference of it. Now, if you play on modded server like playing surf game, you will feel it different. Same with the weapon's recoil and it's relation with player movement. For the recoil, it's now more like a modern shooters, which more realistic than CSS recoil. Also, for the AUG and SSG552, we can aiming down the sight rather than simply "zoomed in", and it has more crosshair sway if you move your character. It makes it harder to land headshots, but its more easier to score body hit. Not saying that doing headshot is impossible, only harder to be compared to CSS and CS1.6. On the environment, it has more interactivity with ingame props and things. For novelty purposes, it's nice. like now the chickens are life-like, you can chase them around, and by that if you play normal game and spot a chicken running away from behind that wall, you know there's something fishy behind it :) All in all, CSGO is a nice to have if you love CS series, and more if you are looking for it's competitive play. But again, CSS is still fun to play, offers more flexibility on mods or custom skins, custom maps to play, and more. Both has it's own strong point, in which CSS still geared towards basic FPS, if you looking for FPS gameplay - or towards fun play, if you play on modded server while CSGO are geared towards competitive play, with little to custom mod your skins and things like that, and supported with multitudes of competitive-ness features. Both are good at different points, and by that I can recommended it for you guys. +1 for the game! *Of course, it's spec requirements also higher than CSS :) Don't worry, if your PC could handle CSS, it could handle CSGO. Don't worry about it. --- Edited for typo... plenty of them =_=

review: Counter Strike: Global Offensive is not a game for the faint of heart. You either make your way through the ranks quick enough, or you run the chance of risking your life. Let me elaborate: The community of this game is renowned to be one of the worst, they would indefinitely skin your entire family if you showed any notion of being a 'noob'. You could also become too engrossed with the diversity of the game, and have your skin mould to your chair. As you can probably imagine, this could cause severe skin problems, and you can die. Finally, in a similar situation, you could once again become quite attached to Counter Strike, and fail to notice that you're dying of starvation, and/or thirst. In a nutshell this game is very dangerous to everyone with 11.99 in their wallets, and I highly recommend you invest quite a lot of your time figuring out if this game is for you.

game-hours: 50.4
review: Since Pokemon captured the heart and soul of literally every child in the world back in the mid 90s, games developers seem to have had only one question on their minds: How do we copy that? Games in which players evolve and/or battle collectible monsters have become ubiquitous in casual gaming, to the point where youre seen as well behind the curve (a dinosaur, if youll pardon the expression) if you have a monster game in which the beasts dont change form. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is not the first to attempt to crack the PokeCode, and it surely wont be the last. But does it have what it takes to be the very best?

review: This game is amazing. Its hard to describe the feeling when you know that your oppenent can show up behind you, and you better hope to Gof that your teammates are covering your back. And you should cover there back, for Global Offensive is the penultimate team FPS, which will keep you coming back to its tight-shooting and rewarding game modes. And if you're tired of the uber-competive classic mode (or you're just ticked off at the long waits between matches), then you can play Dominion or Arms Race, slighlty less exhilharating game modes that give you a bit more space to breath. All game modes are great, and make the game a must-have on your Steam library.

review: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is the epitome of a fantastic and challenging skill-based shooter. You will absolutely hate this game if you suck at it unless you just like to  around in casual mode. If you can get past the scumbag community and find a group of friends that are skilled, yet fun to hang around with, you will love playing this game. I play with a team of a higher caliber and I never get bored of playing with them. I have 2k hours so far, and those hours will continue to increase until a possible new installment comes into fruition. If you want to challenge yourself with a game that you can take a bit more seriously than your average competitive FPS game, Buy. This. Game. You may or may not like it, but if you like it, you will become addicted quickly, and Gaben will steal all of your money that you waste on cases and skins. I speak from experience. This game is brilliant in my eyes. There aren't any other competitive FPS's out there that can rival this one when it comes to a perfect balance of skill and fun all in one. Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a poetic masterpiece. I would recommend this game to anyone who has a mouse and keyboard. The console port sucks. Don't buy it. Alright, Cray signing off.

review: Awesome game! Not having played 1.6, but a bit of Source (mostly casually and messing around with friends), I think I can still safely say, the game has retained what made the earlier titles so fun and addictive (playing CS:GO 'till 5:30 in the morning, yay ... good for your marks :D (at least it was on a Saturday, haha)), and it has a nie skill curve which most games don't have, unfortunately. I basically started playing FPS games with BF3, and I got more hours into it. If you are new to CS and the maps, you will get totally owned at first. But don't worry! Play Deathmatch and some Classic Casual, and it gets better as you play! Don't forget to play Competitive, too, though, as it is way more fun, and the Matchmaking system allows for a semi-fair approach for newer players. (except being matched with complete  "every once in a while", the *Leroy Jenkins* type of ppl that run into B on dust2 as the first guy ... with the bomb ... and get shot ..) Overall, the game allows for loads of fun though ad interested in playing it more seriously, you should easily get a few thousand hours into it! 250 hours for me, and not planning on stopping anytime soon :)

review: Hmmmm, how can I sum this game up. Well, if you're thinking of buying the next Call of Duty, I would think it again. Whats gonna last you more, a effortless piece of amphibian sh*t or a true, fast-paced shooter that had YEARS of effort put into it. I present to you, Counter Strike: Global Offensive. People say the reviewers that put the most hours into a game are the best. Thats simply not true. I put not too much time into this mostly because of other things but I can tell you about my experience with the game. First, the servers are a piece of cake to get into. I took a stopwatch to it and it took literally 3 seconds to find a server. And if your worrying about hacking, dont worry. So far, I have seen no hackers. The community is great. Their are a few people who will hate you, and some ragers, but if you happen to find a 12 year old playing, there not so annoying. I would like to finish off saying this is the most competitive shooter Ive seen in years.

review: I've been playing since Counter-Strike 1.5/1.6, I skipped Counter-Strike: Source, and picked up Global Operations again. Here are my thoughts: This is a wonderful game if people are looking for an FPS to play because of its limited modes. It seems the developers were trying to broaden the gameplay to casual players who are looking for a game to pick up and play and the dedicated players who constantly play to improve. The new modes are: Deathmatch, Gun Game, Demolition, Casual, and Competitive. These modes help players ease into the game with Competitive being an option for more advanced players to partake in. The different modes add a little bit of variety to the game play and can teach players how to control their weapons, positioning, and other mechanics of the game. For me, what makes this game so appealing is the Competitive play. While many serious players go to ESEA or CEVO (gaming leagues) to compete in. The match making in CS:GO isn't bad. It provides a great platform to transition players into competitive play at one of these leagues. The only downside is that the Competitive matches don't have the same settings as the one ESEA or CEVO uses. Last bit of advice for new and veteran players alike, the skill groups in the game do not dictate much. CS:GO was always a team based game and will remain that way even though some of the skilled players can sweep a match up by themselves. In my experience playing CS, I've always found the team that works together will always win even if there's a bit of a skill gap. It's one thing to be outclassed, but its another thing to lose because you were bickering with your teammates.

review: Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars is one of the most acclaimed games to have ever worn Mario's name. An adventure/role-playing title, it was the innovative result of a corporate collaboration -- Nintendo lent its main mascot and his Mushroom Kingdom world to Squaresoft, most known at the time for SNES RPGs like Final Fantasy III and Chrono Trigger, and the company did a remarkable job at expanding the hero's hop-and-bop platforming gameplay into a fully-realized role-playing experience. Though many fans in the mid-'90s were skeptical that it could happen, Mario made the transition to the RPG genre in excellent form. The story begins as any other Mario game, with the Princess getting kidnapped by Bowser and our mustachioed hero heading off in hot pursuit. Things quickly take an unexpected twist, though, when Mario's rescue attempt is defeated by the arrival of another, different villain -- an enormous talking sword that plunges itself into the middle of King Koopa's castle. The weapon, which towers above the top of the fortress and creates the game's central set piece, declares that the Smithy Gang has taken control of the land and there's nothing that any red-capped plumber can do about it. Yeah, sure.

review: This game is... well i want to say really good but it does not deserve too much praise. The gameplay is really good but it is REALLY hard for ex CoD or BF players to get into. But i do actually recommend this game because if you can learn the basics get some friends to play with you it will be alot of fun and im talking about my own experience. Long story short i do recommend this game for fps gamers (and all other gamers too) who are looking for a challange.

review: Would I recommend CS;GO? Depends. Obviously it's a very well known title that almost everyone knows, but its a very competitive game and I wouldn't recommend it to someone who likes more casual games. But, however, there's still a lot of quirky game modes like jail escape and surfing, but then again some other valve games (TF2 for one, which is free) have some of those already. If you are a guy who likes a challenge and wants a competitive skill based game, I would really recommend CS:GO. It's got a lot of replay ability especially if you've got some friends to play with.
